Winey M. Cell. 2001; 106: 95-104Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar, 54Weiss E. Winey M. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 132: 111-123Crossref PubMed Scopus (359) Google Scholar). In this study, using a yeast two-hybrid screen, we identified TTK as a novel CHK2-interacting protein and demonstrated that it binds directly to CHK2, both in vitro and in vivo. We also established a Tet-Off (Clontech) cell line that expressed kinase-dead (KD) TTK (D647A) under the control of tetracycline to investigate the roles of TTK in cell cycle checkpoints. We found that expression of TTK-KD impaired G2/M arrest and CHK2 Thr-68 phosphorylation induced by DNA damage. Similarly, disruption of TTK expression by small interfering RNA (siRNA) also caused a reduction in CHK2 Thr-68 phosphorylation. Finally, we present evidence that TTK exerts its effects possibly by directly phosphorylating CHK2 Thr-68. Together, our data support a model in which TTK functions upstream from CHK2 in response to DNA damage and participates in DNA damage checkpoints through its effects on CHK2. Yeast Two-hybrid Screen—For the yeast two-hybrid screen, the N-terminal domain of CHK2 (residues 1–223) was amplified by PCR and cloned into pDBTrp (Invitrogen) between the SalI and StuI sites. This was used as bait to screen a human testis cDNA library cloned in the pACT2 vector (Clontech). The yeast strains and assay conditions were those used in the ProQuest™ two-yeast system (Invitrogen). Cell Culture Conditions and Treatments—HeLa, MCF7, and 293T cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Hyclone Laboratories) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (Hyclone Laboratories), 100 units/ml penicillin, and 100 μg/ml streptomycin (Invitrogen). HeLa 10-3 and HeLa 6 cells stably transfected, respectively, with the tetracycline-regulated empty pTRE vector or pTRE expressing the TTK-KD (D647A) mutant were generated using the two-step Tet-Off gene expression system. These cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 100 units/ml penicillin, 100 μg/ml streptomycin, 300 μg/ml G418 (Invitrogen), 0.5 μg/ml puromycin (Sigma), and 1 μg/ml tetracycline (Sigma). To induce TTK (D647A) expression, cells were plated in the above medium lacking G418, puromycin, and tetracycline. LNCaP cells were maintained in RPMI 1640 medium (Hyclone Laboratories) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 100 units/ml penicillin, and 100 μg/ml streptomycin. For IR treatment, cells were exposed to 8 Gy, or in the case of U2OS cells, 4 Gy, x-rays using the Torrex 150D inspection system (EG&G), then incubated for the indicated period. For UV irradiation, PBS-washed cells were irradiated in uncovered tissue culture dishes with 254-nm light in a UV cross-linker (Spectronics). The culture medium was then added back and the cells incubated for the indicated period. Plasmids—The pcDNA3 vector (Invitrogen) modified by insertion of sequences encoding a HA tag was used to generate the expression construct for full-length TTK (1–857). pcDNA3-HA-TTK (D647A) was made from the pcDNA-HA-TTK vector by PCR-based site-directed mutagenesis. For Tet-Off expression, a 3.0-kb TTK fragment including 500 bp of the 3′-untranslated region was cloned into the EcoRI site of the pTRE vector (Clontech). For mammalian expression of CHK2, the cDNA was cloned into the BamHI and KpnI sites of the pXJ-myc vector (a kind gift from V. Yu, Institute of Molecular and Cell Biology, Singapore) and expressed as a myc-tagged protein. For expression in Escherichia coli, cDNAs coding for full-length TTK and truncation mutants were cloned into pGEX4T vectors (Amersham Biosciences) for expression as glutathione S-transferase (GST) fusion proteins. Full-length CHK2 or its truncation mutants were expressed from pRSET vectors (Invitrogen) as His-tagged fusion proteins. Recombinant Proteins—GST fusion proteins were expressed in E. coli strain DH5α. After induction with 1 mm isopropyl-β-d-thiogalactopyranoside, the bacteria were lysed by sonication in sonication buffer (50 mm NaH2PO4, 300 mm NaCl, and 20% glycerol) containing 1% Triton X-100 and 1 mg/ml lysozyme, then the lysates were incubated with glutathione-Sepharose beads (Amersham Biosciences) and the bound proteins eluted with 20 mm reduced glutathione. Recombinant His-tagged proteins were expressed in E. coli strain BL21 (DE3) LysE and purified on nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid beads (Qiagen) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The His fusion proteins were eluted with 250 mm imidazole in 50 mm NaH2PO4, pH 8.0, 300 mm NaCl, 20% glycerol, 10 mm β-mercaptoethanol, 0.5 mm PMSF, and 2.5 μg/ml E64, and dialyzed for 30 min against BC0 buffer (20 mm Tris, pH 8.0, 0.2 mm EDTA, and 20% glycerol) containing 0.5 mm dithiothreitol, 0.2 mm PMSF, and 0.05% Nonidet P-40. Antibodies—Rabbit polyclonal anti-TTK antibody was raised against recombinant His-tagged TTK-N (residues 1–386) by LTK Biolaboratories (Taiwan). When used in Western analysis, the antibody detected only one protein with size corresponding to the calculated molecular weight of TTK. It also detected the exogenously expressed HA-TTK (D647A) in HeLa 6 cells (see Fig. 3A). As a comparison, the commercial anti-TTK antibody from Santa Cruz (sc-540) gave the same results. Antibodies against CHK2 (sc-9064), p-CHK2 (Thr-68) (sc-16297-R), Cdc2 (sc-54), and cyclin B1 (sc-245) were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology. Phospho-CHK2 (Thr-68) antibody (2661), phospho-CHK2 (Ser-19) antibody (2666), and anti-Cdc2-phosphotyrosine 15 antibody (9111) were from Cell Signaling Technology. Monoclonal antibodies against CHK2 (K0087) and MAD2 (K0167) were purchased from MBL (Japan). Anti-HA antibody (16B12) was from Covance. Anti-actin antibody (A2066) was purchased from Sigma. Bound primary antibodies were detected using either horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG antibody or horseradish peroxidase-conjugated anti-rabbit IgG antibody (Jackson Immunoresearch) and chemiluminescent reagents (Pierce). Mammalian Cell Lysis and Western Blot Analysis—Whole cell extracts (WCEs) were prepared by resuspending cells in TEGN lysis buffer (10 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 1 mm EDTA, 420 mm NaCl, 10% glycerol, and 0.5% Nonidet P-40) containing 1 mm PMSF, a mixture of protease inhibitors (Roche Applied Science), 10 mm NaF, 10 mm β-glycerophosphate, 5 nm microcystin LR, and 1 mm dithiothreitol. WCEs were boiled for 5 min in protein sample buffer (0.7 m β-mercaptoethanol, 4% SDS, 0.17 m Tris, pH 6.8, 0.17 mg/ml bromphenol blue, 10% glycerol), and a portion (20–30 μg of protein) was analyzed on SDS-polyacrylamide gels. The resolved proteins were wet transferred to PROTRAN nitrocellulose membrane (Schleicher & Schuell), then the blots were blocked for 30 min at room temperature in 1% milk in PBS containing 0.05% Tween 20 and incubated with primary antibody followed by appropriate secondary horseradish peroxidase-conjugated antibody. After washing, the blots were treated with chemiluminescent reagents (Pierce) and exposed to BioMax films (Kodak). Protein-Protein Interaction Assays—For the GST pull-down assay, bacterial lysates containing GST fusion proteins were prepared by sonication as described above, then incubated with glutathione-Sepharose beads for 1 h at 4 °C. After two washes with sonication buffer and one wash with coimmunoprecipitation buffer (10 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 1 mm EDTA, 150 mm NaCl, 10% glycerol, and 0.15% Nonidet P-40), the beads were incubated for 1 h at room temperature in coimmunoprecipitation buffer with 35S-labeled in vitro translated CHK2. After washes with coimmunoprecipitation buffer, bound CHK2 were eluted using 10 mm reduced glutathione and analyzed by SDS-PAGE followed by autoradiography. For coimmunoprecipitation experiments, 293T cells were plated on 60-mm dishes and transiently transfected by calcium phosphate precipitation. At 48 h post-transfection, cells were lysed in TEGN buffer containing 1 mm PMSF, protease inhibitors, 10 mm NaF, 10 mm β-glycerophosphate, 5 nm microcystin LR, and 1 mm dithiothreitol. The WCEs were mixed with an equal volume of TEG buffer (10 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 1 mm EDTA, and 20% glycerol), 15 μl of 50% protein G beads (Pierce), and antibodies. The mixtures were rocked for 2–3 h at 4 °C, then washed three times with 1:1 TEG/TEGN buffer. Bound proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE followed by Western blotting. siRNA Transfection—Transfection of the siRNA was performed as described previously (55Elbashir S.M. Harborth J. Lendeckel W. Yalcin A. Weber K. Tuschl T. Nature. 2001; 411: 494-498Crossref PubMed Scopus (8186) Google Scholar) using Oligofectamine (Invitrogen) and siRNA at a final concentration of 0.15–0.2 μm. Cells were plated at a density of 1 × 105 cells/60-mm dish (HeLa 10-3) or 1 × 105 cells/35-mm dish (U2OS) 1 day before transfection. The sequences targeted by TK1, CHK2, and MAD2 siRNA are 5′-tgaacaaagtgagagacat-3′, 5′-aatgtgtgaatgacaactact-3′, and 5′-aatacggactcaccttgcttg-3′, respectively. Flow Cytometry—For FACS analysis, both attached and floating cells were harvested, resuspended in cold PBS, fixed by adding 10 volumes of cold (–20 °C) methanol, and stored at –20 °C for at least 1 h. Cells were rehydrated with cold PBS and stained for 30 min at 37 °C with 60 μg/ml propidium iodide (Sigma) in PBS containing 50 μg/ml RNase A. The DNA content was analyzed using a FACS Calibur flow cytometer (BD Biosciences). In Vitro Kinase Assay and Immunoprecipitation/Kinase Assay—For the in vitro kinase assay, purified recombinant full-length wild-type (WT) or KD GST-TTK fusion proteins were incubated with purified His-CHK (D347A) for 15 min at 30 °C in kinase buffer (20 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 10 mm MgCl2, 2 mm MnCl2, 1 mm PMSF, and 1 mm dithiothreitol) supplemented with a mixture of protease inhibitors, 10 mm NaF, 5 nm microcystin LR, and 50 μm ATP. The reaction was stopped by the addition of a 0.5 volume of 3× protein sample buffer and the proteins resolved by SDS-PAGE followed by detection with anti-CHK2-phosphothreonine 68 rabbit polyclonal antibody (2661, Cell Signaling Technology). For immunoprecipitation/kinase assays, TTK was first immunoprecipitated from LNCaP or MCF7 cell lysates with anti-TTK (sc-540), washed twice in 1:1 TEG/TEGN buffer, once in 1:1 TEG/TEGN buffer containing 0.7 m LiCl, and twice in kinase buffer. Kinase assay was then performed as described above using His-CHK2-D347A as substrate. TTK Interacts with CHK2 Both in Vitro and in Vivo—To delineate the CHK2-mediated signaling pathways, we conducted a yeast two-hybrid screen using the CHK2 N-terminal domain (1–243) as bait to isolate novel CHK2-interacting proteins. By screening a human testis cDNA library, we obtained several positive clones. One of the clones, d2, encoded 470 amino acid residues encompassing the C-terminal portion (amino acids 387–857) of TTK (42Mills G.B. Schmandt R. McGill M. Amendola A. Hill M. Jacobs K. May C. Rodricks A.M. Campbell S. Hogg D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 16000-16006Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), the human homolog of the yeast dual specific protein kinase, Mps1. Human Mps1, like its yeast counterpart, plays an essential role in the spindle assembly checkpoint (45Stucke V.M. Sillje ́ H.H.W. Arnaud L. Nigg E.A. EMBO J. 2002; 21: 1723-1732Crossref PubMed Scopus (210) Google Scholar, 54Weiss E. Winey M. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 132: 111-123Crossref PubMed Scopus (359) Google Scholar) To determine whether TTK interacted directly with CHK2, an in vitro GST pull-down assay was performed using 35S-labeled in vitro translated CHK2 and bacterially produced GST fusion constructs of TTK (Fig. 1A). As shown in Fig. 1B, the originally cloned d2 (387–857) construct and the d2C (521–857) construct, but not GST, brought down CHK2 in vitro. The KD mutant d2 (D647A) also bound to CHK2, demonstrating that the kinase activity of TTK was not essential for the interaction in vitro. The interaction, although specific, was not strong. It is possible that bacteria-expressed recombinant d2 protein lacks additional modification or was not properly folded for optimal interaction

The TIM23 complex of the mitochondrial inner membrane mediates the import of preproteins that contain positively charged targeting signals. This translocase consists of the two phylogenetically related membrane-embedded subunits Tim17 and Tim23 to which four largely hydrophilic subunits, Tim50, Tim44, Tim16, and Tim14, are attached. Whereas in vitro reconstitution experiments have suggested a pore-forming capacity of recombinant Tim23, virtually nothing is known about the properties and function of Tim17. We employed a combined genetic and biochemical approach to address the function of Tim17 in preprotein translocation. Tim17 exposes an N-terminal hydrophilic stretch into the intermembrane space. Truncation of the first 11 amino acid residues of this stretch did not affect the stability or integrity of TIM23 subunits but strongly impaired the import of preproteins. Moreover, expression of the truncated Tim17 variant led to a dominant negative effect on the mitochondrial membrane potential. By an alanine-scanning approach we identified two conserved negative charges in the N terminus of Tim17 as critical for Tim17 function. The replacement of these positions by positively charged residues results in a strong growth defect, which can be cured by reverting two conserved positive charges into aspartate residues between transmembrane domains two and three of Tim17. On the basis of these observations we propose that charged residues in Tim17 are critical for the preprotein-induced gating of the TIM23 translocase. These form amphiphilic helices with one positively charged and one hydrophobic face (7von Heijne G. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 1335-1342Crossref PubMed Scopus (712) Google Scholar). Presequences are recognized by receptors on the surface of mitochondria, which are part of a multisubunit translocation machinery, the TOM complex (translocase of the outer membrane). Sequential interactions of the presequences with binding sites on both sides of the outer membrane then guide the preproteins to and across the protein-conducting channel of the TOM complex (8Komiya T. Rospert S. Koehler C. Looser R. Schatz G. Mihara K. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 3886-3898Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 9Mayer A. Neupert W. Lill R. In the intermembrane space, preproteins with presequences are recognized by the translocase of the inner membrane, the TIM23 1The abbreviations used are: TIM, translocase of the inner membrane; DiSC3(5), 3,3′-dipropylthiadicarbocyanine iodide; DSG, disuccinimidyl glutarate; wt, wild-type; DHFR, dihydrofolate reductase. complex. The TIM23 complex of Saccharomyces cerevisiae consists of six subunits, all of which are essential for viability: Tim50, Tim44, Tim23, Tim17, Tim16/Pam16, and Tim14/Pam18. Tim50 contains one N-terminal transmembrane span and exposes a large C-terminal receptor domain into the intermembrane space (10Geissler A. Chacinska A. Truscott K.N. Wiedemann N. Brandner K. This domain interacts with incoming polypeptide chains and passes them on to the membrane-embedded subunits Tim23 and Tim17. Tim17 and Tim23 are phylogenetically related and contain a conserved core segment of four transmembrane domains. Tim23, in contrast to Tim17, exposes an N-terminal hydrophilic domain of about 100 amino acid residues into the intermembrane space that appears to cooperate with Tim50 in the recognition of preproteins (10Geissler A. Cell Biol. 1997; 137: 377-386Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 15Truscott K.N. Kovermann P. Geissler A. Merlin A. Meijer M. Driessen A.J. Rassow J. Pfanner N. Wagner R. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2001; 8: 1074-1082Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar). Based on these findings it was proposed that Tim23 forms the core subunit of the translocase representing the minimal functional unit for complete translocation of preproteins across the inner membrane into the matrix. Little is known on the function of the Tim17 subunit and it was speculated that Tim17 may form a second, Tim23-independent channel that mediates membrane integration of inner membrane proteins by a stop-transfer mechanism (16Pfanner N. Chacinska A. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2002; 1592: 15-24Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). Translocation of the presequence across the TIM23 complex depends on the membrane potential which may exert an electrophoretic force on the positively charged presequences and thereby initiate the transport of preproteins across the inner membrane. In addition, the membrane potential may play a role in the mechanism by which the peptide-conducting channel is opened. In the matrix, the presequence is bound by the mitochondrial Hsp70 chaperone. Hsp70 is recruited to the import sites via Tim44, a matrix protein that is associated with Tim17 and Tim23. Preprotein binding by Hsp70 is controlled by the J domain proteins Tim14 and Tim16, both stable subunits of the TIM23 complex, and the soluble nucleotide exchange factor Mge1 (17Kozany C. Mokranjac D. Sichting M. Neupert W. Hell K. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2004; 11: 234-241Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar, 18Frazier A.E. Dudek J. Guiard B. Voos W. Li Y. Lind M. Meisinger C. Geissler A. Sickmann A. Meyer H.E. Bilanchone V. Cumsky M.G. Truscott K.N. Pfanner N. Rehling P. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2004; 11: 226-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar, 19Truscott K.N. Cell Biol. 2003; 163: 707-713Crossref PubMed Scopus (163) Google Scholar, 20Mokranjac D. Sichting M. Neupert W. Hell K. EMBO J. 2003; 22: 4945-4956Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar). In an ATP-dependent reaction, Hsp70 mediates the vectorial translocation of the preprotein into the matrix and finally assists in the folding of the polypeptide into its native, three-dimensional structure (5Neupert W. Brunner M. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2002; 3: 555-565Crossref PubMed Scopus (301) Google Scholar). In this study we have analyzed structure-function relationships of Tim17. We show that the N-terminal intermembrane space segment of Tim17 contains a strictly conserved motif harboring two negatively charged residues, which are crucial for the function of the TIM23 translocase. Truncation of this signature severely affected the import of preproteins into mitochondria, regardless of whether they are destined for the matrix or the inner membrane. Our data suggest that Tim17, together with Tim23, plays both a general and critical role for the translocation of preproteins across the inner membrane of mitochondria. Recombinant DNA Techniques and Plasmid Constructions—Standard methods were used for DNA manipulations (21Sambrook J. Fritsch E.F. Maniatis T. Nolan C. Molecular Cloning. 2nd Ed. CSH Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar). The complete TIM17 open reading frame was obtained by amplification of genomic yeast DNA using the primers SM28 (5′-GGGCTGCAGATGTCAGCCGATCATTCGAGAG-3′) and SM29 (5′-GGGGGATCCCTAAGCTTGCAGAGGTTGAGAG-3′). To obtain the TIM17ΔN sequences, which contain codons 12–158 of the TIM17 gene, the primers SM30 (5′-GGGCTGCAGATGATAGTAATACTAAATGATTTC-3′) and SM29 were used. Primers SM28 and SM31 (5′-GGGGGATCCCTATCTTTGAAACATTAGTCCCAC-3′) were used to amplify the sequence for TIM17ΔC, which encoded residues 1–134 of Tim17. The resulting sequences were digested with PstI and BamHI and subcloned into the URA3-containing pVT100U expression vector (22Vernet T. Dignard D. Thomas D.Y. Gene (Amst.). 1987; 52: 225-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (465) Google Scholar). For site-specific mutagenesis, the TIM17 gene was amplified by PCR using the primers SM42 (5′-GGGGTCGACCCACTGTCAGTGGCG-3′) and SM43 (5′-GGGTCTAGAGAGAGAAATGGTTGG-3′). The resulting sequence was digested with SalI and XbaI and subcloned into pRS315 (23Sikorski R.S. Hieter P. Genetics. 1989; 122: 19-27Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Specific alanine replacement mutations in the TIM17 sequence were introduced via PCR primers using the QuickChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). For expression of the Cox5aΔTM protein, the sequences corresponding to amino acid residues 1–98 and 119–153 of Cox5a were amplified by PCR and cloned in-frame into the EcoRI and BamH1 site of pGEM4 (Promega, Madison, WI). The Cox5aΔTM-DHFR expression construct was derived from this plasmid by insertion of the mouse DHFR sequence between the BamHI and HindIII sites. Strains and Growth Conditions—S. cerevisiae strains were isogenic to the wild-type strain BY4743 (24Brachmann C.B. Davies A. Cost G.J. Caputo E. Li J. Hieter P. Boeke J.D. Yeast. 1998; 14: 115-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (2645) Google Scholar). A heterozygote TIM17 deletion strain (GenBank™ accession no. Y21282, Euroscarf, Frankfurt, Germany) was used for generation of tim17 mutants. This strain was transformed with URA3-containing pVT100U vectors expressing full-length or truncated versions of Tim17. Homozygote deletions carrying the plasmids were selected following sporulation and tetrad analysis. The strain expressing the full-length Tim17 protein is referred to as Tim17FL, and the strains expressing the N- or C-terminal deletion mutants as Tim17ΔN and Tim17ΔC, respectively. For expression of Tim17ΔN in addition to the endogenous Tim17, the pVT100U Tim17ΔN vector was transformed into BY4743. For generation of alanine replacement mutants, pRS315 plasmids containing the LEU2 and tim17 genes were transformed into the Tim17ΔN mutant. The resulting strains were grown in the presence of uracil to allow for the loss of the pVT100U plasmids, and ura3 autotrophic cells were selected by growth on 5-fluoroorotic acid (25Boeke J.D. LaCroute F. Fink G.R. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1984; 197: 345-346Crossref PubMed Scopus (1712) Google Scholar). Yeast strains were cultivated at 30 °C on lactate medium or on selective medium supplemented with 2% KOH-buffered lactate (26Herrmann J.M. Fo ̈lsch H. Neupert W. Stuart R.A. Celis J.E. Cell Biology: A Laboratory Handbook. 1. Academic Press, San Diego, CA1994: 538-544Google Scholar). In Vitro Protein Import and Mitochondrial Subfractionation—Mitochondria were isolated as described previously (26Herrmann J.M. Fo ̈lsch H. Neupert W. Stuart R.A. Celis J.E. Cell Biology: A Laboratory Handbook. 1. Academic Press, San Diego, CA1994: 538-544Google Scholar). Import of in vitro synthesized proteins into isolated mitochondria was performed according to published procedures (27Herrmann J.M. Neupert W. Stuart R.A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 2217-2226Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar). Standard import reactions were carried out in the presence of 2 mm NADH, 2 mm ATP, 10 mm creatine phosphate, and 0.1 mg/ml creatine kinase. Mitochondria were converted to mitoplasts by 10-fold dilution in ice-cold 20 mm Hepes pH 7.4. Protease treatment was performed by addition of 50 μg/ml proteinase K to the reaction and incubation for 30 min at 0 °C. The efficiency of swelling and proteinase K treatment was monitored by Western blotting using Dld1, OxaI, and Mge1 as marker proteins representing the intermembrane space, the inner membrane, and the matrix, respectively. Chemical Cross-linking and Immunoprecipitation—For cross-linking, the dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) domain in precursor proteins was stabilized by incubation of the reticulocyte lysate with 0.1 mm methotrexate and 1 mm NADPH for 10 min at 25 °C. Then the lysate was added to isolated mitochondria that were resuspended in import buffer lacking bovine serum albumin with 2 mm ATP, 2 mm NADH, 2 mm methotrexate, and 5 mm NADPH. After incubation for 5 min at 25 °C, 200 μm disuccinimidyl glutarate (DSG) was added to the mitochondria, and the reaction was incubated for 30 min on ice. Cross-linking was stopped by the addition of 100 mm glycine, pH 8.0. Mitochondria were reisolated, washed, and lysed in 1% SDS, 300 mm NaCl and 1 mm EDTA. After a clarifying spin for 30 min at 47,000 × g the extract was diluted 20-fold in 0.2% Triton X-100, 150 mm NaCl, 20 mm sodium phosphate pH 7.5 and used for immunoprecipitation according to published procedures (28Herrmann J.M. Westermann B. Neupert W. Methods Cell Biol. 2001; 65: 217-230Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The extract was added to 25 μl of protein A-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences, Uppsala, Sweden) and 4–6 μl of rabbit antisera or 20 μl of affinity-purified antibody. After incubation for 2 h at 4 °C, the beads were washed twice in Triton buffer and once in phosphate-buffered saline. Precipitated proteins were dissolved in sample buffer, separated by SDS-PAGE, and autoradiographed. To purify the TIM23 complex of the different mutants, 150 μg of mitochondria were lysed in 50 μl of 1% digitonin, 50 mm NaCl, 30 mm HEPES pH 7.4, 2 mm EDTA, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride and diluted 20-fold in 0.1% digitonin, 50 mm NaCl, 30 mm HEPES pH 7.4, 2 mm EDTA, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. After a clarifying spin for 30 min at 47,000 × g, the extract was added to 25 μl of protein A-Sepharose and 20 μl of purified Tim23 antibody. Gel Filtration Analysis—To determine the size of the TIM23 complex in wild-type and mutant mitochondria, mitochondria (400 μg) were lysed in 1% digitonin, 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 10% glycerol, 50 mm sodium phosphate, pH 8.0. The lysate was clarified by centrifugation at 100,000 × g for 20 min at 4 °C and loaded on a Superose 6 (HR10/30) column (Amersham Biosciences). Proteins in the fractions were precipitated by addition of 12% trichloroacetic acid, resolved on SDS-PAGE, and analyzed by Western blotting. The signals of Tim17 were quantified by densitometry. Determination of Mitochondrial Membrane Potential—The membrane potential of isolated mitochondria was measured in 0.6 m sorbitol containing 0.1% (w/v) bovine serum albumin (fatty acid-free), 0.5 mm EDTA, 10 mm MgCl2, and 20 mm potassium phosphate pH 7.2 at 25 °C as described (29Ga ̈rtner F. Voos W. Querol A. Miller B.R. Craig E.A. Cumsky M.G. Pfanner N. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 3788-3795Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar, 30Szyrach G. Ott M. Bonnefoy N. Neupert W. Herrmann J.M. EMBO J. 2003; 22: 6448-6457Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar). 3,3′-Dipropyl thiadicarbocyanine iodide (DiSC3, Ref. 5Neupert W. Brunner M. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2002; 3: 555-565Crossref PubMed Scopus (301) Google Scholar) was added to a final concentration of 0.7 μm. After 0.5–1 min (time point 1) mitochondria were added to a final protein concentration of 10 μg/ml. After 2–5 min of incubation, 1 mm KCN and 10 μm valinomycin were added to dissipate the membrane potential (time point 2). The increase of the fluorescent signal corresponds to the relative membrane potential level of the mitochondria. Tim17 Sequences Contain a Conserved N-terminal Motif— Tim17 is a highly conserved protein. Alignments of plant, fungal, and animal homologues show a very high number of identical or chemically similar amino acid residues (Fig. 1A). Between the Tim17 orthologues of human, S. cerevisiae, and Arabidopsis, 44% of the residues are identical. Conserved residues are mainly positioned within the hydrophobic transmembrane spans, but are also present in the hydrophilic loops exposed to the intermembrane space and the matrix (Fig. 1B). Whereas the C-terminal intermembrane space tail of Tim17 is highly variable, the N terminus shows a number of residues that are conserved between plants, fungi, and animals. In contrast, the Tim17 paralogue Tim23 shows a lower degree of conservation and residues identical among Tim23 orthologues are restricted to the hydrophobic core domains of the protein (Fig. 1B). Truncation of the N terminus of Tim17 Strongly Affects Growth—Tim17 differs from Tim22 and Tim23 mainly in the regions flanking the hydrophobic core domain. To assess the functional relevance of these tail domains we constructed yeast mutants expressing Tim17 variants in which these tails were truncated (Fig. 2A). To obtain these mutants, one TIM17 allele was deleted in a diploid strain. This strain was transformed with URA3 plasmids expressing the full-length or truncated versions of Tim17 lacking the C-terminal 24 (Tim17ΔC) or the N-terminal 11 amino acid residues (Tim17ΔN). After sporulation of the cells, haploid mutants were selected that exclusively expressed the plasmid-encoded variants of Tim17. Deletion of the C-terminal intermembrane space domain of Tim17 did not affect growth on fermentable and only mildly on non-fermentable carbon sources. Therefore, this non-conserved region appears not to be crucial for Tim17 function (Fig. 2B). In contrast, truncation of the N terminus of Tim17 resulted in a severe growth defect both on fermentable and non-fermentable carbon sources (Fig. 2B, last row). From this we conclude that the N-terminal 11 residues of Tim17 are critical for function of the protein. The Tim17ΔN Mutant Shows a Normal Composition of the TIM23 Complex—We tested whether the truncation of the N-terminal domain of Tim17 affects the integrity of the TIM23 complex. We first assessed the levels of the subunits of the TIM23 complex by Western blotting of mitochondria isolated from wild-type and the Tim17ΔN mutant (Fig. 3A). This revealed comparable levels of the six subunits of the TIM23 translocase as well as of mitochondrial Hsp70. The levels of the truncated Tim17 protein were somewhat higher than the levels of the endogenous Tim17 because of the plasmid-based expression of the protein. Thus, the truncation of the N terminus of Tim17 does not result in the depletion of the mutant Tim17 protein or of other constituents of the TIM23 machinery. Are the subunits of the TIM23 complex properly assembled in the Tim17ΔC mutant? To assess the integrity of the TIM23 complex, mitochondria were lysed with digitonin, and proteins associated with Tim23 were isolated by co-immunoprecipitation (Fig. 3B). In wild-type and Tim17ΔN mitochondria, Tim17 was efficiently recovered together with Tim23, as well as the other TIM23 components Tim50, Tim44, Tim16, and Tim14. Furthermore, upon size exclusion chromatography a comparable fractionation behavior of wild-type and mutant Tim17 was observed (Fig. 3C). No monomeric, unassembled Tim17ΔN protein was detected in the mutant. These results strongly suggest that the truncation of the N-terminal intermembrane space domain of Tim17 does not affect the integrity of the TIM23 complex. Truncation of the N terminus of Tim17 Severely Diminishes Mitochondrial Import of Preproteins—Does the truncation of the N terminus of Tim17 affect the import rates of preproteins destined to the different subcompartments of mitochondria? To answer this question, we first tested whether accumulated precursor forms of mitochondrial proteins can be detected in extracts of Tim17ΔN cells (Fig. 4A). In wild-type cells, Hsp60 was exclusively found in its mature form. In contrast, a large fraction of Hsp60 was present as precursor form in the Tim17ΔN mutant. A similar accumulation of Hsp60 precursor was observed in cells depleted of Tim17 (Fig. 4A, Tim17↓). This suggests that the truncation of the N terminus of Tim17 leads to an import defect of mitochondrial precursor proteins in vivo. To assess the import of mitochondrial proteins in more detail, radiolabeled preproteins were synthesized in reticulocyte lysate and incubated with mitochondria isolated from wild-type or Tim17ΔN cells. The kinetics of protein import were assessed by taking aliquots after various times of incubation (Fig. 4B). The import rates of preproteins destined for the mitochondrial matrix, like Su9-(1–69)-DHFR or F1β (Fig. 4B, Su9 and F1β) were greatly diminished in the Tim17ΔN mitochondria. Similarly, the import rates of inner membrane proteins like the subunit 5a of the cytochrome oxidase (Fig. 4B, Cox5a) were reduced. This protein contains one transmembrane span, which arrests translocation of the preprotein in the TIM23 channel and leads to integration into the inner membrane. Deletion of the transmembrane domain of Cox5a causes missorting into the matrix (31Glaser S.M. Miller B.R. Cumsky M.G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 1873-1881Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). This matrix-targeted variant still required the N-terminal Tim17 domain for efficient import (Fig. 4B, Cox5aΔTM). Import of cytochrome b2, an intermembrane space protein that is imported in a presequence- and TIM23-dependent manner, was likewise affected in Tim17ΔN mitochondria. The mitochondrial ATP/ADP carrier (AAC), which is integrated into the inner membrane by the TIM22 translocase was used as a control; import of this TIM23-independent protein was not affected in Tim17ΔN mitochondria. In summary, the truncation of the N terminus of Tim17 causes a rather general import defect of presequence-containing precursor proteins, regardless of whether they are targeted to the matrix, the inner membrane or the intermembrane space. Expression of the Truncated Tim17 Protein Leads to a Partial Dissipation of the Mitochondrial Membrane Potential—The membrane potential across the inner membrane is essential for the import of preproteins into mitochondria and reduced membrane potential levels are known to lead to diminished import rates of proteins (32Martin J. Mahlke K. Pfanner N. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 18051-18057Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To assess whether a diminished membrane potential might explain the strong import defects observed in Tim17ΔN mutants, we measured the membrane potential levels in wild-type and mutant mitochondria (Fig. 5A). The fluorescent dye, DiSC3 (5Neupert W. Brunner M. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2002; 3: 555-565Crossref PubMed Scopus (301) Google Scholar), was added to isolated mitochondria (Fig. 5A, time point 1); this dye is partially taken up by the organelles leading to a decrease of the fluorescent signal. Valinomycin was then added to the sample to deplete the membrane potential (Fig. 5A, time point 2). Because of the depletion of the membrane potential by valinomycin the dye is released into the medium. The ensuing increase of fluorescent signal directly corresponds to the level of membrane potential. Comparable membrane potential levels were observed in mitochondria of wild-type cells and the mutant complemented with full-length Tim17. In contrast, the Tim17ΔN mitochondria showed a strongly reduced membrane potential, which could either be the cause or the consequence of impaired import rates in the mutant. The TIM23 complex has the ability to form ion-conducting channels in the inner membrane (14Lohret T.A. Jensen R.E. Kinnally K.W. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 137: 377-386Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 15Truscott K.N. Kovermann P. Geissler A. Merlin A. Meijer M. Driessen A.J. Rassow J. Pfanner N. Wagner R. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2001; 8: 1074-1082Crossref PubMed Scopus (256) Google Scholar). The observed reduced membrane potential could indicate an uncontrolled leakage of ions across the inner membrane due to the truncation of Tim17. In this case, expression of the truncated Tim17 protein in a wild-type background should also cause a partial dissipation of the membrane potential. Therefore, we tested whether expression of Tim17ΔN in wild-type mitochondria exhibits a dominant effect on the level of membrane potential. As shown in Fig. 5B, indeed a significantly reduced level of membrane potential was observed in mitochondria containing both wild-type and truncated Tim17. We conclude that truncation of the N terminus of Tim17 leads to a strong reduction of the mitochondrial membrane potential even in the presence of wild-type Tim17 protein. The Import Defect of Tim17ΔN Mitochondria Is Not Caused by a Diminished Membrane Potential Level—To measure protein import rates in Tim17ΔN mitochondria independent of their endogenous energetic conditions, we established an artificial membrane potential across the inner membrane (33Pfanner N. Neupert W. EMBO J. 1985; 4: 2819-2825Crossref PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). In the presence of valinomycin membranes become permeable to potassium ions. The selective diffusion of potassium ions can be used to generate comparable levels of membrane potential in wild-type and Tim17ΔN mitochondria (Fig. 6A). This artificial membrane potential can efficiently drive the import reaction in wild-type mitochondria (Fig. 6B, open circles). However, the import rates of preproteins were still significantly reduced in mitochondria of the Tim17ΔN mutants (Fig. 6B, filled circles). Thus, the diminished import efficiencies observed in the mutant are not indirectly caused by the reduced membrane potential. Passage of Preproteins through the TIM23 Complex Is Strongly Impaired in Tim17ΔN Mitochondria—Which stage of the import reaction of preproteins is affected in Tim17ΔN mitochondria? The Tim17ΔN mitochondria showed significantly reduced levels of imported preproteins. As a consequence, import experiments with isolated mitochondria showed strongly diminished amounts of preproteins that were matured by the matrix protease MPP (Fig. 7A). In these experiments, no protease-resistant precursor protein was observed indicating that preproteins remained at least partially outside of the outer membrane of the mitochondria. To address the location of the accumulated import intermediates more carefully, we employed a cross-linking approach. We constructed a fusion protein consisting of the matrix-destined preprotein Cox5aΔTM and mouse dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). We chose the Cox5aΔTM protein because of its extremely fast import kinetics at 25 °C which allows the import of enough preprotein into Tim17ΔN mitochondria to detect potential contacts of the preprotein by cross-linking. The DHFR domain of this protein was tightly folded by addition of the folate analogue methotrexate and incubated with mitochondria expressing either full-length Tim17 (Tim17FL) or Tim17ΔN. The tight folding of the DHFR domain prevents complete import and t

The crystal structure of Escherichia coli nitrate reductase A (NarGHI) in complex with pentachlorophenol has been determined to 2.0 Å of resolution. We have shown that pentachlorophenol is a potent inhibitor of quinol:nitrate oxidoreductase activity and that it also perturbs the EPR spectrum of one of the hemes located in the membrane anchoring subunit (NarI). This new structural information together with site-directed mutagenesis data, biochemical analyses, and molecular modeling provide the first molecular characterization of a quinol binding and oxidation site (Q-site) in NarGHI. A possible proton conduction pathway linked to electron transfer reactions has also been defined, providing fundamental atomic details of ubiquinol oxidation by NarGHI at the bacterial membrane. The crystal structure of Escherichia coli nitrate reductase A (NarGHI) in complex with pentachlorophenol has been determined to 2.0 Å of resolution. We have shown that pentachlorophenol is a potent inhibitor of quinol:nitrate oxidoreductase activity and that it also perturbs the EPR spectrum of one of the hemes located in the membrane anchoring subunit (NarI). This new structural information together with site-directed mutagenesis data, biochemical analyses, and molecular modeling provide the first molecular characterization of a quinol binding and oxidation site (Q-site) in NarGHI. A possible proton conduction pathway linked to electron transfer reactions has also been defined, providing fundamental atomic details of ubiquinol oxidation by NarGHI at the bacterial membrane. Escherichia coli, when grown anaerobically in the presence of nitrate, synthesizes the membrane-bound quinol:nitrate oxidoreductase NarGHI 1The abbreviations used are: NarGHI, nitrate reductase holoenzyme; PCP, pentachlorophenol; HOQNO, 2-n-heptyl-4-hydroxyquinoline-N-oxide; r.m.s.d., root main square deviation; MOPS, 4-morpholinepropanesulfonic acid; PBH2, plumbagin; UQH2, ubiquinol; FdnGHI, formate dehydrogenase; FQ, fluorescence quench. (1Bertero M.G. Rather R.A. Palak M. Hou C. Lim D. Blasco F. Weiner J.H. Strynadka N.C. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2003; 10: 681-687Crossref PubMed Scopus (412) Google Scholar, 2Blasco F. Guigliarelli B. Magalon A. Asso M. Giordano G. Rather R.A. Cell. Mol. Life Sci. 2001; 58: 179-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar). This enzyme has been the subject of intense biochemical, biophysical, and structural studies. The protein complex contains three subunits with characteristic redox prosthetic groups: NarG (140 kDa), the catalytic subunit with a molybdo-bis(molybdopterin guanine dinucleotide) cofactor and an [Fe-S] cluster (FS0); NarH (58 kDa), the electron transfer subunit with four [Fe-S] clusters (FS1, FS2, FS3, and FS4); NarI (26 kDa), the integral membrane subunit with two b-type hemes, termed bP and bD to indicate their proximal (bP) and distal (bD) positions to the catalytic site. NarG and NarH form a soluble cytoplasmically localized catalytic domain anchored to the membrane by NarI. NarGHI catalyzes electron transfer from a quinol binding site located in NarI through the redox cofactors aligned as an “electric wire” through the complex (bD → bP → FS4 → FS3 → FS2 → FS1 → FS0) to the molybdo-bis(molybdopterin guanine dinucleotide cofactor in NarG, where nitrate is reduced to nitrite. NarGHI often forms a respiratory chain with the formate dehydrogenase FdnGHI via the lipid soluble quinol pool. Electron transfer from formate to nitrate is coupled to proton translocation across the cytoplasmic membrane generating proton motive force by a redox loop mechanism (3Mitchell P. J. Theor. Biol. 1976; 62: 327-367Crossref PubMed Scopus (927) Google Scholar). In the redox loop mechanism proton translocation is the net result of the topographically segregated reduction of quinone and oxidation of quinol on opposite sites of the membrane. The high resolution structures of both respiratory complexes, FdnGHI and NarGHI, have been recently solved (1Bertero M.G. Rather R.A. Palak M. Hou C. Lim D. Blasco F. Weiner J.H. Strynadka N.C. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2003; 10: 681-687Crossref PubMed Scopus (412) Google Scholar, 4Jormakka M. Tornroth S. Byrne B. Iwata S. Science. 2002; 295: 1863-1868Crossref PubMed Scopus (407) Google Scholar). Crystallographic analysis of FdnGHI has shown the presence of a quinone reduction site oriented toward the cytoplasm (4Jormakka M. Tornroth S. Byrne B. Iwata S. Science. 2002; 295: 1863-1868Crossref PubMed Scopus (407) Google Scholar). Existing biochemical and biophysical evidence indicates that the quinol binding and oxidation functionality of NarGHI is provided by the NarI subunit (5Rather R.A. Blasco F. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 5260-5268Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar, 6Rather R.A. Blasco F. Magalon A. Asso M. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 12747-12757Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 7Magalon A. Rather R.A. Lemesle-Meunier D. Frixon C. Weiner J.H. Blasco F. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 10851-10856Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar), but no high resolution structural information has been made available to date. We have solved the crystal structure at 2.0 Å of resolution of NarGHI in complex with the quinol binding inhibitor pentachlorophenol (PCP), which is structurally related to the physiological quinol substrates of the enzyme. This structure shows the existence of a periplasmically oriented Q-site in NarI (termed QD in reference to its close proximity to the heme bD), confirming previous spectrophotometric and kinetic results (6Rather R.A. Blasco F. Magalon A. Asso M. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 12747-12757Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 7Magalon A. Rather R.A. Lemesle-Meunier D. Frixon C. Weiner J.H. Blasco F. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 10851-10856Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar, 8Zhao Z. Rather R.A. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 5403-5413Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar, 9Zhao Z. Rather R.A. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 14225-14233Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). Further structural and functional studies within the QD-site are also presented using site-directed mutants of conserved residues in its vicinity. Collectively, this work provides significant new insight into the electron transfer and proton conduction pathways through the transmembrane subunit NarI. Magalon A. Asso M. Bertrand P. Frixon C. Giordano G. Blasco F. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 4828-4836Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar) carrying a single point mutation, C26A in NarH. Growth of Cells—E. coli LCB79/pVA700 was grown overnight in 5 liter batches with a 1% inoculum in a B. Braun Biostat B fermenter at 30 °C in the presence of 100 μg ml–1 ampicillin and 100 μg ml–1 streptomycin. The growth medium contained 12 g liter–1 Tryptone, 24 g liter–1 yeast extract, 5 g liter–1 NaCl, and 4 ml liter –1 glycerol. NarGHI overexpression was induced at A600 = 2.0, after which the cultures were grown for 10–11 h. Cells were harvested by centrifugation, washed in a buffer containing 100 mm MOPS and 5 mm EDTA, and frozen in liquid nitrogen for subsequent storage at –70 °C. Isolation of Membrane Fractions and Purified Preparations—Crude membrane vesicles were prepared from E. coli cells by French pressure cell lysis and differential centrifugation (12Rather R.A. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 8296-8305Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 12747-12757Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). All membrane preparation steps were carried out in a buffer containing 100 mm MOPS and 5 mm EDTA (pH 7.0). Excess sucrose was removed by resuspension and recentrifugation in this buffer. Purified NarGHI was prepared by anion exchange chromatography on a DEAE-FF column (Amersham Biosciences) as described by Bertero et al. (1Bertero M.G. Rather R.A. Palak M. Hou C. Lim D. Blasco F. Weiner J.H. Strynadka N.C. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2003; 10: 681-687Crossref PubMed Scopus (412) Google Scholar). J. 1998; 332: 35-41Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar). Optical data were recorded using a Hewlett Packard (Agilent) HP8453 spectrophotometer. McDermott M.T. Weiner J.H. Biochem. J. 1998; 332: 35-41Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar). Crystallization, Data Collection, and Structure Determination of the NarGHI-PCP Complex—Highly ordered crystals of three single point mutants of NarGHI, C26A in NarH and K86A and H66Y in NarI, were obtained in conditions similar to those reported earlier for the native enzyme (1Bertero M.G. Rather R.A. Palak M. Hou C. Lim D. Blasco F. Weiner J.H. Strynadka N.C. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2003; 10: 681-687Crossref PubMed Scopus (412) Google Scholar). Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 4828-4836Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar) and allowed us to obtain crystals yielding higher resolution data than that obtained with crystals of the native enzyme after soaking with PCP. Single datasets for each mutant were collected at 100 K at the Advanced Light Source (beamlines 8.2.1 and 8.2.2). Crystals were isomorphous with the native crystals. Biol. 1999; 125: 156-165Crossref PubMed Scopus (2022) Google Scholar) and refinement with CNS allowed us to obtain the final models (R/Rfree values of 0.200/0.234 for NarGHI-PCP, R/Rfree values of 0.186/0.212 for NarGHI-K86A, R/Rfree values of 0.188/0.237 for NarGHI-H66Y). Graph. 1988; 24: 219-220Crossref Google Scholar). A summary of data collection and refinement statistics is shown in Table I. Open table in a new tab PCP Is a Potent Inhibitor of NarGHI—NarGHI is able to use both menaquinol and ubiquinol (UQH2) as physiological electron donors (Figs. 1, a and b) (27Wallace B.J. Young I.G. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1977; 461: 84-100Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar, 28Brondijk T.H. Fiegen D. Richardson D.J. Cole J.A. Mol. Microbiol. 2002; 44: 245-255Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). Studies of quinol binding to NarGHI have been expedited by the use of the menaquinone analog HOQNO (Fig. 1d), which has been demonstrated to inhibit enzyme activity by binding to a single site in close proximity to heme bD within NarI (6Rather R.A. Blasco F. Magalon A. Asso M. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 12747-12757Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 7Magalon A. Rather R.A. Lemesle-Meunier D. Frixon C. Weiner J.H. Blasco F. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 10851-10856Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). We have so far been unable to produce crystals of the NarGHI-HOQNO complex, so we pursued the characterization of other potential inhibitors of the enzyme. PCP (Fig. 1c) has been shown to be a potent inhibitor of both succinate dehydrogenase and fumarate reductase (29Maklashina E. Cecchini G. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1999; 369: 223-232Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar). We have characterized the effects of this inhibitor on the activity of the native NarGHI and NarGHI bearing a specific mutation of a highly conserved residue in NarI (NarI-K86A). The NarI-K86A mutant has a lower plumbagin:nitrate oxidoreductase activity than the wild-type enzyme, 10 s–1 compared with 68 s–1, respectively. The decreased activity of the mutant enzyme suggests that the NarI Lys-86 residue is probably located in the vicinity of a functional Q-site within the NarGHI complex. Fig. 2 shows the effect of HOQNO and PCP on the plumbagin:nitrate (PBH2:NO–3) oxidoreductase activity of the native enzyme and of the NarI-K86A mutant. HOQNO inhibits NarGHI with an I50 of ∼1.5 μm but has little inhibitory effect on the NarI-K86A mutant (Fig. 2A). PCP is a significantly more potent inhibitor than HOQNO, with an I50 of ∼0.4 μm. The NarI-K86A mutant also attenuates the inhibitory effect of PCP but not to the same extent as is observed with HOQNO, with the I50 increasing to ∼2.5 μm (Fig. 2B). To gain a more detailed understanding of the inhibitory effect of PCP, we subjected the wild-type enzyme to steady-state kinetic analyses in the presence of PCP. PBH2 is oxidized by NarGHI with an estimated Km of 147 ± 17 μm. Interestingly, PCP exhibits mixed inhibition with a competitive inhibitor binding constant (Kic) of 57 ± 14 nm and an uncompetitive inhibitor binding constant of 490 ± 9 nm. The relative magnitudes of these constants suggest that the inhibition elicited by PCP is mixed, but primarily competitive in nature. To determine whether the PCP binding site is equivalent to the HOQNO binding site identified by biophysical means, we performed fluorescence (FQ) titrations which exploit the fluorescent properties of the latter inhibitor. HOQNO binds to the wild-type enzyme with an affinity of ∼250 nm, but it does not bind with high affinity to the NarI-K86A mutant (Fig. 3A). This result is in agreement with the inhibition data presented in Fig. 2A. Furthermore, competition between HOQNO and PCP occurs at an equivalent site within the NarGHI complex (Fig. 3B). The addition of 5 μm PCP to the fluorescence cuvette before performing a FQ titration with HOQNO essentially eliminates detectable HOQNO binding. A fluorescence increase is observed when the enzyme is incubated in the presence of 2.7 μm HOQNO and titrated with PCP (Fig. 3B), consistent with PCP being able to displace HOQNO from its binding site. Overall, the FQ data demonstrate the presence of a common binding site for PCP and HOQNO within the NarGHI complex. To further rationalize the PCP inhibitory effect, we recorded EPR spectra of the hemes of oxidized NarGHI and NarI-K86A mutant (Fig. 4). As previously reported (6Rather R.A. Blasco F. Magalon A. Asso M. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 12747-12757Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 7Magalon A. Rather R.A. Lemesle-Meunier D. Frixon C. Weiner J.H. Blasco F. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 10851-10856Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar), HOQNO elicits a shift in the gz of heme bD from 3.36 to 3.50 (Fig. 4, A and B). PCP produces a similar shift on bD from 3.36 to 3.45 (Fig. 4, A and C). Neither inhibitor alters the gz feature of the heme bP spectrum. The NarI-K86A mutation has no significant effect on the gz of heme bD (Fig. 4D). HOQNO and PCP elicit shifts in the heme bD gz of the NarI-K86A mutant from 3.36 to 3.39 and from 3.36 to 3.48, respectively (Fig. 4, E and F). As for the wild-type enzyme, no PCP or HOQNO effects are observed on heme bP gz. Overall, these results are consistent with the kinetic and FQ data (Figs. 2 and 3). To explain the inhibitory effects of PCP and the behavior of the NarI-K86A mutant, we have determined the crystal structure of the wild-type and mutant enzymes in the presence and absence of inhibitor. The Structural Environment of the PCP Binding Site—The NarI subunit (225 aa) consists of five tilted transmembrane helices numbered sequentially from I to V, with the N and C terminus located toward the periplasmic and the cytoplasmic side of the membrane, respectively (Fig. 5a). The four helices II to IV are arranged in a bundle which accommodates the two hemes, bP and bD. Each heme is coordinated by two conserved histidine residues, His-56 and His-205 for bP and His-66 and His-187 for bD. Helices IV and V are connected by two extra helices, IV′ and IV″, which are in a hairpin-like arrangement and located on the periplasmic side. The C terminus of NarI extends into the cytoplasmic domain of the enzyme, establishing extensive interactions with both NarG and NarH. The structure of NarI reveals two hydrophobic clefts (Fig. 5b), an elongated cavity (A) located between helices I, II, and IV′ that exposes the edges of both hemes to the membrane and a smaller pocket (B) that is delimited by helices II, III, and IV′ and leads to heme bD. Both clefts, with the exclusion of bulk solvent, represent plausible locations for Q-sites. To structurally characterize the PCP binding site, NarGHI crystals were soaked in the presence of this inhibitor, and the structure of the NarGHI-PCP complex was determined to 2.0 Å of resolution (Table I, Fig. 5). The Cα backbone of the NarI subunit from the NarGHI-PCP complex superposes with NarI of the native enzyme with a root main square deviation (r.m.s.d.) of only 0.14 Å for 217 C-α atoms (as determined with Protein Structure Comparison Service SSM at the European Bioinformatics Institute (30Krissinel E. Henrick K. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D. Biol. Crystallogr. 2004; 60: 2256-2268Crossref PubMed Scopus (3189) Google Scholar)). The initial Fo – Fc difference electron density map, calculated before inclusion of the inhibitor molecule into the model, clearly reveals the presence of one PCP molecule intimately bound to NarI. Refinement statistics indicate the PCP is likely bound with full occupancy to NarI, and temperature factor analysis supports the strong binding of the inhibitor with average thermal parameters of the PCP very similar to that of the surrounding NarI residues (38 and 33 Å2, respectively). The PCP binding pocket (pocket B in Fig. 5b) is located between transmembrane helices II and III, in close proximity to heme bD toward the periplasmic side of the membrane (Fig. 5a). The PCP aromatic ring binds in a cavity formed by primarily nonpolar residues; three glycine residues (Gly-65, Gly-69, and Gly-94) and Met-70 from helix II, Met-89 and Ala-90 from helix III, and Met-156 and Val-160 from a short helix connecting helices IV and V (Fig. 6a). The majority of these residues (Gly-65, Gly-69, Ala-90, and Gly-94) are highly conserved in the NarI proteins from different bacterial species (31Rather R.A. Blasco F. Magalon A. Weiner J.H. J. Mol. Microbiol. Biotechnol. 2001; 3: 273-283PubMed Google Scholar). Although the nature of the pocket is primarily hydrophobic (Fig. 5b), a few significant hydrogen bonds between PCP and NarI are also observed. The hydroxyl group of PCP is hydrogen-bonded to one of the propionate groups of bD and to Nϵ-H66 (2.8-Å distance from both ligands, Fig. 6a). H66 simultaneously coordinates the heme bD iron atom via the side chain Nδ atom. The edge-to-edge distance between the heme bD and PCP is 2.8 Å, which is well within the physiological limits for electron transfer (32Page C.C. Moser C.C. Chen X. Dutton P.L. Nature. 1999; 402: 47-52Crossref PubMed Scopus (1531) Google Scholar). In light of these observations, we propose that the observed PCP pocket mimics the physiological QD-site. We have modeled an ubiquinol molecule in this cavity with the head group overlapping with the PCP aromatic ring (Figs. 6, a and b). One hydroxyl group (position 1) of UQH2 points in the same direction as the hydroxyl group of the inhibitor, suggesting a pathway for the electron transfer to the heme cofactor. The hydroxyl group on the opposite site of the quinol molecule (position 4) is oriented as Cl4, and the long alkyl chain extends gradually toward the opening of the hydrophobic cleft stabilized by Met-89, Ala-93, Val-64, and Gly-65. The PCP binding pocket can also accommodate a menaquinol molecule (Fig. 6c), suggesting a potential multifunctional Q-site for both napthoquinol and benzoquinol substrates. Structural Characterization of the Mutant Lys-86 in NarI— The conserved residue Lys-86 in NarI is located at one end of the PCP binding pocket (Fig. 6a). The positively charged Nζ of Lys-86 has no logical hydrogen bond donor with the chlorinated PCP and lies ∼6 Å from the Cl4 atom in the inhibitor. However, our molecular modeling of the physiological substrate UQH2 based on the PCP position suggests that relatively small conformational movements of the Lys-86 side chain could allow it to play a role in substrate stabilization, providing a hydrogen bond donor for the hydroxyl oxygen at position 4 (analogous to Cl4 in PCP) (Fig. 6b). To prove our hypothesis, we have determined the crystal structure of NarGHI carrying the singlepoint mutation K86A in NarI, previously characterized by kinetic, FQ, and EPR experiments (Figs. 2, 3, 4). The structure of NarGHI-K86A (1.9-Å resolution; Table I) is highly similar to the native structure (r.m.s.d. of 0.12 Å for 217 superposed Cα atoms in NarI (30Krissinel E. Henrick K. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D. Biol. Crystallogr. 2004; 60: 2256-2268Crossref PubMed Scopus (3189) Google Scholar)), indicating that the structural integrity of the PCP binding pocket has been largely preserved in this mutant form. In addition, after soaking the NarGHI-K86A crystals with PCP, the inhibitor can still bind to the QD site. On the other hand, our fluorescence quench titration experiments showed that NarGHI-K86A has much lower affinity for the menaquinol analog HOQNO compared with the native enzyme (Fig. 3A) (6Rather R.A. Blasco F. Magalon A. Asso M. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 12747-12757Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar) and has a lower plumbagin:nitrate oxidoreductase activity (10 s–1) than the wild-type NarGHI (68 s–1). Overall, the experimental data strengthen our working model that Lys-86 is an essential residue in defining the Q-site and that the binding of ubiquinol as well as menaquinol electron donors can occur at our structurally defined pocket. Structural Characterization of the Mutant H66Y in NarI—In native NarGHI the Nδ side-chain atoms of the highly conserved His-66 (helix II) and His-187 (helix V) in NarI provide direct coordination to the iron atom of the heme bD. It has been shown that the single point mutation of His-66 to tyrosine (H66Y) prevents the insertion of the heme bD as well as the binding of quinol analogs and inhibitors. Consequently, no quinol-dependent heme reduction is detected (7Magalon A. Rather R.A. Lemesle-Meunier D. Frixon C. Weiner J.H. Blasco F. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 10851-10856Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar, 9Zhao Z. Rather R.A. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 14225-14233Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). However, in the NarGHI-PCP complex structure we present here the 13.2-Å edge-to-edge distance between the heme bP and the bound PCP could still support electron transfer even in the absence of heme bD (32Page C.C. Moser C.C. Chen X. Dutton P.L. Nature. 1999; 402: 47-52Crossref PubMed Scopus (1531) Google Scholar). To understand the molecular basis for the effect of the H66Y mutation on quinol-dependent activity, we have determined the crystal structure of NarGHI-H66Y to 2.5-Å resolution (Fig. 7). The structure is very similar to the native NarGHI, with a r.m.s.d. of only 0.27 Å for 211 common Cα between the NarI-H66Y subunit and the native NarI (30Krissinel E. Henrick K. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D. Biol. Crystallogr. 2004; 60: 2256-2268Crossref PubMed Scopus (3189) Google Scholar). As expected, NarI-H66Y shows only one redox center, the heme bP. No electron density for the distal heme bD is observed at any level in our maps. It appears that in the absence of the heme bD, the structure is stabilized in a native-like conformation via a hydrogen bond between Tyr-66-OH and His-187-Nδ (∼3.0 Å). A localized but major change is also observed for the transmembrane helix II, where no electron density is observed for a stretch of residues from the mutated Tyr-66 to Leu-81 (Thr-72 to Leu-81 is also highly disordered in the native enzyme). This disordered region contains two residues, Gly-69 and Met-70, which directly form one side of the PCP binding pocket. The less rigid protein environment around the potential QD site explains the loss of PCP, HOQNO, and quinol binding in the mutant enzyme. Proton Pathway from the PCP Binding Site—Experimental evidence shows that NarI allows for the coupling of quinol oxidation and proton translocation toward the periplasm (31Rather R.A. Blasco F. Magalon A. Weiner J.H. J. Mol. Microbiol. Biotechnol. 2001; 3: 273-283PubMed Google Scholar). The two propionate groups of bD in NarI point toward the periplasmic face of the membrane. Between the propionates and the bulk solvent (∼9 Å distance from the surface) there exists a network of water molecules formed by Trp-580, Trp-595, Trp-676, and Trp-677 (also present in the native structure, Protein Data Bank code 1Q16). The observed water molecules (temperature factors range from 28 to 48 Å2 at full occupancy) are buried within NarI and are the only water molecules observed within the transmembrane helices. These waters form several hydrogen bonds among themselves and with both the propionate groups of heme bD, the main chain nitrogen atoms of Ser-154, Glu-155, Met-156, and the side chains of the highly conserved Ser-143, Ser-147, and Gln-87 (Fig. 6a). This water channel suggests a possible proton pathway from the QD-site to the periplasm. We have presented herein the crystal structure of nitrate reductase A (NarGHI) in complex with the specific inhibitor PCP at 2.0 Å resolution. The high quality electron density map shows that the bound PCP is well ordered in the structure corroborating the measured affinity of NarI for this compound (Kic = 57 nm). The close proximity of PCP to heme bD (edge-to-edge distance of only 2.8 Å) and the significant change in the EPR line shape of bD elicited by this compound are highly suggestive that PCP mimics the physiological quinol electron donors. Furthermore, the location of the PCP binding pocket is consistent with the involvement of both hemes in electron transfer from quinol to nitrate (1Bertero M.G. Rather R.A. Palak M. Hou C. Lim D. Blasco F. Weiner J.H. Strynadka N.C. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2003; 10: 681-687Crossref PubMed Scopus (412) Google Scholar, 6Rather R.A. Blasco F. Magalon A. Asso M. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 12747-12757Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 12Rather R.A. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 8296-8305Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). The PCP binding pocket is located in the narrow hydrophobic cleft B (Fig. 5b), which provides a more ideal spatial constriction for the correct quinol orientation compared with the wider cleft A. Molecular modeling shows that both physiological electron donors, ubiquinol and menaquinol, can occupy the PCP binding pocket, supporting the proposal of a multifunctional site in NarI. This hypothesis is also strengthened by the mainly competitive inhibitory effect of PCP (an UQH2 analog) on NarGHI activity in the presence of plumbagin (a menaquinol analog). In addition, mutation of the amino acid Lys-86, which lines the proposed Q-site, to a neutral residue affects HOQNO (a menaquinol analog) binding. The QP-site in E. coli fumarate reductase represents a similar example of a multifunctional site. In fact, crystallographic analysis has shown that the two inhibitors, DNP-19 and HOQNO, can both bind at QP. It has to be noted that these molecules adopt different locations within the same pocket (33Iverson T.M. Luna-Chavez C. Croal L.R. Cecchini G. Rees D.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 16124-16130Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). It is conceivable that also within QD of NarI, menaquinol and ubiquinol occupy different positions, and further structural studies will be pursued with diverse analogs and inhibitors. The available information for many quinone-reactive sites in different respiratory and photosynthetic complexes shows very weak sequence and structural similarities (34Fisher N. Rich P.R. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 296: 1153-1162Crossref PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar). However, the Q-site identified in our study contains some critical residues that have been observed in other respiratory proteins. For example, His-66, which coordinates heme bD, is positioned within hydrogen-bonding distance from the hydroxyl group of PCP. Histidine residues are emerging as a common theme in quinol/quinone binding, and in particular, a heme-ligand histidine functioning as a quinone-ligand has been described in E. coli FdnGHI, the redox partner of NarGHI during nitrate respiration (4Jormakka M. Tornroth S. Byrne B. Iwata S. Science. 2002; 295: 1863-1868Crossref PubMed Scopus (407) Google Scholar). Furthermore, our mutagenesis studies have shown the importance of another residue, Lys-86, for NarI functionality. Similarly, in E. coli fumarate reductase a lysine residue in close proximity to the quinone molecule at the QP-site plays a potential role in proton shuttling (33Iverson T.M. Luna-Chavez C. Croal L.R. Cecchini G. Rees D.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 16124-16130Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). A second Q-site in NarI has been recently proposed according to the available kinetic data (9Zhao Z. Rather R.A. Weiner J.H. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 14225-14233Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). The elongated hydrophobic cavity A (Fig. 5b) where both hemes are exposed is a good candidate for a secondary quinone reactive site. On the other hand, the apolar pocket A does not contain any ionizable group as found in a number of Q-sites, including QP in E. coli fumarate reductase (35Iverson T.M. Luna-Chavez C. Cecchini G. Rees D.C. Science. 1999; 284: 1961-1966Crossref PubMed Scopus (366) Google Scholar), QD in Wolinella succinogenes fumarate reductase (36Lancaster C.R. Gorss R. Haas A. Ritter M. Mantele W. Simon J. Kroger A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 13051-13056Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar), and QD in E. coli FdnGHI (4Jormakka M. Tornroth S. Byrne B. Iwata S. Science. 2002; 295: 1863-1868Crossref PubMed Scopus (407) Google Scholar). This observation suggests that the hypothetical secondary Q-site may be important for structural integrity of NarI with possible electron transfer but not proton translocation activities. The lack of density for any quinone molecule at this site in the native and NarGHI-PCP complex structures could be due to the presence of Thesit during the purification of the complex. In fact, tubular-shaped densities, which can be modeled as the aliphatic chains of detergent or lipid molecules, were observed in this cavity in the native NarGHI structure (1Bertero M.G. Rather R.A. Palak M. Hou C. Lim D. Blasco F. Weiner J.H. Strynadka N.C. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2003; 10: 681-687Crossref PubMed Scopus (412) Google Scholar). Quinol oxidation by NarI leads to electron transfer through the prosthetic groups of the enzyme as well as proton release into the periplasm. The chain of water molecules located between the propionates of heme bD and the bulk solvent recalls a “proton wire,” which has been proposed in other respiratory enzymes such as E. coli FdnGHI (4Jormakka M. Tornroth S. Byrne B. Iwata S. Science. 2002; 295: 1863-1868Crossref PubMed Scopus (407) Google Scholar) and the yeast cytochrome bc1 complex (37Hunte C. Koepke J. Lange C. Rossmanith T. Michel H. Structure Fold. Des. 2000; 8: 669-684Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (516) Google Scholar). Assuming that the PCP binding site functions as a Q-site, we suggest a potential quinol oxidation mechanism. (i) A fully reduced ubiquinol molecule binds to the site in NarI. The hydroxyl group in position 1 of UQH2 forms hydrogen bonds to one of the bD propionates and to His-66. (ii) One electron is transferred to bD, the first redox cofactor in the Nar chain, and one proton is shuttled toward the periplasm via the propionate group and the water channel illustrated in the structure. A semiquinone intermediate species is formed. (iii) The second electron is transferred with complete oxidation of quinol to quinone. A second proton has to be released, and Lys-86 could provide the pathway for the proton to the aqueous milieu. The fully oxidized ubiquinone must now dissociate to allow further enzyme turnover. We thank Delilah Mroczko for assistance with the B. Braun Biostat B fermentation system. We also thank the Department of Energy and staff at the Advanced Light Source, beamlines 8.2.1/8.2.2, for access to synchrotron radiation.

General strategies to obtain inactive kinases have utilized mutation of key conserved residues in the kinase core, and the equivalent Lys72 in cAMP-dependent kinase has often been used to generate a “dead” kinase. Here, we have analyzed the consequences of this mutation on kinase structure and function. Mutation of Lys72 to histidine (K72H) generated an inactive enzyme, which was unphosphorylated. Treatment with an exogenous kinase (PDK-1) resulted in a mutant that was phosphorylated only at Thr197 and remained inactive but nevertheless capable of binding ATP. Ser338 in K72H cannot be autophosphorylated, nor can it be phosphorylated in an intermolecular process by active wild type C-subunit. The Lys72 mutant, once phosphorylated on Thr197, can bind with high affinity to the RIα subunits. Thus a dead kinase can still act as a scaffold for binding substrates and inhibitors; it is only phosphoryl transfer that is defective. Using a potent inhibitor of C-subunit activity, H-89, Escherichia coli-expressed C-subunit was also obtained in its unphosphorylated state. This protein is able to mature into its active form in the presence of PDK-1 and is able to undergo secondary autophosphorylation on Ser338. Unlike the H-89-treated wild type protein, the mutant protein (K72H) cannot undergo the subsequent cis autophosphorylation following phosphorylation at Thr197. Using these two substrates and mammalian-expressed PDK-1, we can elucidate a possible two-step process for the activation of the C-subunit: initial phosphorylation on the activation loop at Thr197 by PDK-1, or a PDK-1-like enzyme, followed by second cis autophosphorylation step at Ser338. The phosphate on Thr197 in the activation loop of the C-subunit interacts with His87 of the C helix, Arg165 adjacent to the catalytic base, Asp166, Thr195 on the activation loop, and Lys189 in β-strand 9, which positions Arg190 to interact with the A helix. These interactions act in a synergistic fashion with the phosphate, helping to bring these residues to their proper spatial orientation, but they also anchor the phosphate and consequently the activation segment in a conformation required for activity (8Toner-Webb J. van Patten S.M. Walsh D.A. Taylor S.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 25174-25180Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Mutagenesis of Thr197 and Ser338 demonstrated their importance for full activity (9Adams J.A. McGlone M.L. Gibson R. Taylor S.S. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 2447-2454Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar, 10Yonemoto W. McGlone M.L. Grant B. Taylor S.S. Protein Eng. 1997; 10: 915-925Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). Many protein kinases, the structures of which have been solved in the unphosphorylated inactive form, show that the position of this loop differs from that of the phosphorylated enzyme (Fig. 1C) (8Toner-Webb J. van Patten S.M. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 3079-3089Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar).In many kinases, phosphorylation of the activation loop is a highly dynamic process triggered by a specific signal. In contrast, although PKA is also a phosphoprotein, it is not activated by phosphorylation of its activation loop in response to a signaling event. Instead, the fully phosphorylated enzyme is assembled with inhibitory regulatory subunits. Its activity in cells is thus controlled primarily by regulatory subunits (R-subunits) that bind the C-subunit with high affinity in the absence of cAMP (16Doskeland S.O. Ogreid D. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 2291-2301Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This mode of activation in which the regulatory and catalytic moieties are separate proteins is unusual in the protein kinase family. Although the C-subunit can be readily phosphorylated in vitro by 3-phosphoinositide-dependent protein kinase-1 (PDK-1), it also undergoes autophosphorylation when it is expressed in E. coli (17Moore M.J. Kanter J.R. Jones K.C. Taylor S.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 47878-47884Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). Furthermore, mutant forms of the C-subunit that are defective in autophosphorylation are readily phosphorylated in mammalian cells, whereas mutants that are defective in recognition by PDK-1 are not phosphorylated (18Steinberg R.A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1991; 11: 705-712Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). However, nothing is known about the conformation of the C-subunit in its unphosphorylated state, and very little is known about the process by which the inactive dephosphorylated protein is converted into a fully phosphorylated protein prior to its association with regulatory subunits.In addition to these essential phosphorylation sites, there are various key residues in the kinase core that play a significant role in the stability and the functional organization of the kinase. One such residue, Lys72 located in subdomain II in the Hanks classification (19Hanks S.K. Quinn A.M. Hunter T. Science. 1988; 241: 42-52Crossref PubMed Scopus (3782) Google Scholar), represents one of the most conserved residues in the protein kinase core. This was the first residue to be identified in the active site of a protein kinase (Fig. 1D). The absolute conservation of this residue in every protein kinase subsequently reinforced its importance. This residue was first found to be important for kinase function of the C-subunit using an ATP affinity analog FSBA. The alkylating group on FSBA occupies the region of the protein that recognizes the phosphates of ATP (20Jacobson M.A. Colman R.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 1454-1460Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 21Bhatnagar D. Hartl F.T. Roskoski Jr., R. Lessor R.A. Leonard N.J. Biochemistry. 1984; 23: 4350-4357Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar), and treatment of the C-subunit with FSBA resulted in inactivation that was protected in the presence of MgATP. Peptide sequencing later identified the modified residue as Lys72 (22Zoller M.J. Nelson N.C. Taylor S.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 10837-10842Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Treatment with a hydrophobic carbodiimide, dicyclohexylcarbodiimide, in the absence of MgATP also irreversibly inhibited the C-subunit, due to cross-linking of Lys72 to Asp184, another conserved residue (23Buechler J.A. Taylor S.S. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 2065-2070Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar).In this work, we have addressed two questions. First, we ask what are the functional consequences of mutation of lysine 72? Second, can this “dead” kinase be used to probe the pathway whereby the C-subunit is activated by phosphorylation? To achieve this, Lys72 was replaced with His, Arg, Ala, and Met. Additionally, to provide a suitable comparison with the inactive C-subunit, the wild type C-subunit was expressed in the presence of a PKA inhibitor, H-89. This C-subunit is not phosphorylated. Using phospho-specific antibodies, we show that both H-89 and the Lys72 mutants are excellent substrates for PDK-1 at Thr197; however, only wild type C-subunit can be phosphorylated at Ser338 and thus converted into an active enzyme. These results define a two-step activation process dependent on an intramolecular autophosphorylation at Ser338. In addition, we show that phosphorylation at Thr197 is sufficient for RIα binding, thus defining a new role for the activation loop independent of its role in coordinating the active site conformation. Thus the dead enzyme is still capable of forming a holoenzyme complex once it is phosphorylated.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESMaterials—Reagents were obtained as follows: pRSETB expression vector (Invitrogen), [γ-32P]ATP (PerkinElmer Life Sciences), Escherichia coli strains BL21(DE3) (Novagen, Madison, WI), H-89 (LC Laboratories, Woburn, MA), Muta-Gene site directed mutagenesis kit and Affi-Gel (Bio-Rad), horseradish peroxidase-conjugated anti-rabbit IgG (Amersham Biosciences), Gammabind G-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences), pcDNA-3 eukaryotic expression vector (Invitrogen), Super-Signal West Pico chemiluminescent substrate detection kit (Pierce), oligonucleotides (Genosis-Sigma), the PepTag PKA activity assay kit (Promega, Madison, WI), and Effectene transfection kit (Qiagen, Valencia, CA).
