Cell Biol. 2004; 36: 1171-1186Crossref PubMed Scopus (490) Google Scholar, 12Bruzzone R. White T.W. Paul D.L. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 238: 1-27Crossref PubMed Scopus (1226) Google Scholar, 13Goodenough D.A. Goliger J.A. Paul D.L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1996; 65: 475-502Crossref PubMed Scopus (1060) Google Scholar). To date, phosphorylation sites of Cx43 for several protein kinases have been mapped, and a relationship between phosphorylation of these sites and gap junctional coupling state is being established (11Lampe P.D. Lau A.F. Int. J. Biochem. Cell Biol. 2004; 36: 1171-1186Crossref PubMed Scopus (490) Google Scholar). Thus, it is important and timely to investigate the nature of protein kinases and phosphatases interacting with Cx43 under particular physiological and pathological conditions. The Src family kinases were among the first protein kinases known to interact with Cx43 and to regulate gap junctional coupling. For instance, v-Src expression in mammalian cells can induce phosphorylation at Tyr-247 and Tyr-265 of Cx43 and subsequent inhibition of gap junctional intercellular communication, which has been proposed to underlie the transformation of mammalian cells transfected with Rous sarcoma virus (11Lampe P.D. Lau A.F. Int. J. Biochem. Cell Biol. 2004; 36: 1171-1186Crossref PubMed Scopus (490) Google Scholar, 14Warn-Cramer B.J. Lau A.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2004; 1662: 81-95Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). v-Src has also been shown to bind directly to Cx43 and to induce tyrosine phosphorylation both in vitro and in vivo (11Lampe P.D. Lau A.F. Int. J. Biochem. Cell Biol. 2004; 36: 1171-1186Crossref PubMed Scopus (490) Google Scholar, 14Warn-Cramer B.J. Lau A.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2004; 1662: 81-95Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). c-Src, the cellular homolog of v-Src, is believed to interact with Cx43 in a similar manner. For example, reagents such as lysophosphatidic acid and thrombin that are known to activate c-Src signaling pathways and exogenous overexpression of wild-type c-Src have each been shown to cause tyrosine phosphorylation of Cx43 and a reduction of gap junctional coupling (15Postma F.R. Hengeveld T. Alblas J. Giepmans B.N. Zondag G.C. Jalink K. Moolenaar W.H. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 140: 1199-1209Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar, 16Toyofuku T. Akamatsu Y. Zhang H. Kuzuya T. Tada M. Hori M. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 1780-1788Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (183) Google Scholar, 17Giepmans B.N. Hengeveld T. Postma F.R. Moolenaar W.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 8544-8549Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar). Moreover, exogenous wild-type c-Src has been shown to bind to endogenous Cx43 in cardiac myocytes and fibroblasts (16Toyofuku T. Akamatsu Y. Zhang H. Kuzuya T. Tada M. Hori M. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 1780-1788Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (183) Google Scholar, 17Giepmans B.N. Hengeveld T. Postma F.R. Moolenaar W.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 8544-8549Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar). However, it has been controversial whether endogenous c-Src interacts with endogenous Cx43 and whether such interaction regulates gap junctional coupling (13Goodenough D.A. Goliger J.A. Paul D.L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1996; 65: 475-502Crossref PubMed Scopus (1060) Google Scholar, 16Toyofuku T. Akamatsu Y. Zhang H. Kuzuya T. Tada M. Hori M. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 1780-1788Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (183) Google Scholar, 17Giepmans B.N. Hengeveld T. Postma F.R. Moolenaar W.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 8544-8549Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar, 18Loo L.W. Kanemitsu M.Y. Lau A.F. Mol. Carcinog. 1999; 25: 187-195Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). In a recent study we found that c-Src association with Cx43 was markedly increased in astrocytes when intracellular pH was reduced, suggesting that the interaction between Cx43 and c-Src is a regulated process that may occur during acidosis (19Duffy H.S. Ashton A.W. O'Donnell P. Coombs W. Taffet S.M. Delmar M. Spray D.C. Circ. Res. 2004; 94: 215-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). In this model the intracellular acidosis was induced by a collapse of transmembrane potassium concentration gradient in the presence of nigericin. This is an intriguing finding since we previously reported that both ischemia, which causes intercellular acidosis, and increased extracellular potassium concentration can induce dephosphorylation of Cx43 in astrocytes (20Li W.E.I. Ochalski P.A. Hertzberg E.L. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 1998; 10: 2444-2463Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar, 21Nagy J.I. Li W.E.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 4567-4572PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, increased association between Cx43 and c-Src during intracellular acidosis may be related to an alteration in the phosphorylation state of Cx43. In this study we tested this hypothesis in cultured cortical astrocytes, which express abundant Cx43 as their primary gap junction protein. Moreover, we and others have previously shown that dephosphorylation of Cx43 can be induced in rat astrocytes in vivo after ischemia and in vitro under the conditions described below (10Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 2644-2650Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, 22Cotrina M.L. Kang J. Lin J.H. Bueno E. Hansen T.W. He L. Liu Y. Nedergaard M. J. Neurosci. 1998; 18: 2520-2537Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Reagents—Dulbecco's modification of Eagle's medium and Hanks' balanced salt solution were obtained from Cellgro (Herndon, VA), trypsin, fetal bovine serum, and antibiotics were from Invitrogen, and tissue culture dishes were obtained from Fisher. Sodium iodoacetate (I-9148) and sodium cyanide (S-3296) were obtained from Sigma. Polyclonal antibodies against MKP-1 (M-18) and c-Src (SC-18) were obtained from Santa Cruz Biotechnology (Santa Cruz, CA); a v-Src antibody (OP07) was from Calbiochem; three monoclonal anti-Cx43 antibodies were from Zymed Laboratories Inc. (13-8300, South San Francisco, CA, designated Zy13) and Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center (Cx43CT1 and Cx43NT1); a polyclonal anti-ERK1/2 antibody (06-182) and a monoclonal anti-phosphotyrosine antibody (05-321) were from Upstate Biotechnology Inc. (Lake Placid, NY); a monoclonal β-actin antibody was from Sigma (A-5441); a polyclonal glial fibrillary acidic protein antibody was from Dako (Z0334, Carpinteria, CA). A well characterized affinity-purified polyclonal anti-Cx43 antibody termed 18A was also used in this study (10Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 2644-2650Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, 20Li W.E.I. Ochalski P.A. Hertzberg E.L. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 1998; 10: 2444-2463Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar, 23Hertzberg E.L. Saez J.C. Corpina R.A. Roy C. Kessler J.A. Methods. 2000; 20: 129-139Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Primary Culture of Mouse Cortical Astrocytes and Induction of Acidosis and Chemical Ischemia/Hypoxia (CIH)—Primary cortical astrocytes were obtained from postnatal day 2 mouse pups as described (10Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 2644-2650Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Briefly, pups were sacrificed using isofluorane and decapitated, and brains were removed from the skull into cold phosphate-buffered saline solution. The cerebral cortices were dissected, cleared from leptomeninges, chopped into 0.5-mm3 pieces, digested in 0.25% trypsin solution for 30 min at 37 °C, triturated using flame-polished Pasteur pipettes, and centrifuged at 1200 × g for 10 min. The resulting supernatant was removed, the pellet was resuspended in Dulbecco's modification of Eagle's medium containing 10% fetal bovine serum, and cells were plated into 100-mm plastic Petri dishes (Fisher) and allowed to grow for 24 h before the culture medium was changed. All cultured cells were maintained in this medium, which was changed three times a week. In contrast to cultured rat astrocytes, mouse astrocytes prepared with this protocol were virtually free of microglia and oligodendrocytes based on the appearance and immunostaining using the glial fibrillary acidic protein antibody (more than 95% positive, not shown). Astrocytes cultured for 3–4 weeks and passaged twice were used for this study. Intracellular acidosis and CIH were induced according to protocols described previously (10Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 2644-2650Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, 19Duffy H.S. Ashton A.W. O'Donnell P. Coombs W. Taffet S.M. Delmar M. Spray D.C. Circ. Res. 2004; 94: 215-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). Briefly, intracellular acidosis of astrocytes was induced by 30 min of incubation in a 145 mm KCl solution containing 10 μm nigericin at pH 7.4, 7.1, 6.8, and 6.5. For induction of CIH, astrocytes were incubated for 30 min in Hanks' balanced salt solution containing 0.3 mm sodium iodoacetate and 1 mm sodium cyanide at 37 °C. Scrape Loading of Lucifer Yellow—The gap junctional coupling between astrocytes was determined using scrape loading of Lucifer yellow in confluent astrocytes according to the protocol described (15Postma F.R. Hengeveld T. Alblas J. Giepmans B.N. Zondag G.C. Jalink K. Moolenaar W.H. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 140: 1199-1209Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar, 19Duffy H.S. Ashton A.W. O'Donnell P. Coombs W. Taffet S.M. Delmar M. Spray D.C. Circ. Res. 2004; 94: 215-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). Briefly, a straight incision was made in astrocytes in the presence of divalent cation-free phosphate-buffered saline containing 0.5% Lucifer yellow. After 2 min, Lucifer yellow solution was removed from the culture, which was subsequently washed in regular phosphate-buffered saline and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde. The distance of spread of Lucifer yellow from the incision to neighboring cells was measured and analyzed using the Scion Image software. Immunoprecipitation and Western Blotting—All procedures were performed at 4 °C unless otherwise noted. Cultured astrocytes were harvested into a RIPA buffer containing 1% Nonidet P-40, 10 mm sodium deoxycholate, protease inhibitors (P-8340, Sigma), 10 mm sodium fluoride, and 1 mm sodium orthovanadate (pH 7.4). The cell suspension was subsequently sonicated and centrifuged at 12,000 × g for 20 min. The supernatant was collected, and the protein concentration was determined using a Pierce BCA kit to ensure that very similar amounts of protein samples were loaded for Western blotting analysis or for immunoprecipitation (IP). Moreover, the equivalency of protein loading in Western blots using whole cell lysates was further confirmed by Western blots of GAPDH using a monoclonal antibody against GAPDH (RD1-TRK5G4–6C5, Research Diagnostics Inc., shown in Fig. 1, A2). About 10% of sample was used for direct Western blotting analysis to determine the general profile of protein expression and the phosphorylation state of Cx43. The rest was used for protein co-IP studies. For protein co-IP, astrocyte lysates were preincubated with 40 μl of recombinant protein G-agarose (15920-010, Invitrogen) for 30 min and centrifuged briefly to get rid of agarose beads. The supernatant was incubated with corresponding IP antibody overnight before a 1-h incubation with fresh agarose beads. This IP mixture was centrifuged, supernatant was removed, and the immunocomplex on agarose beads was washed six times using RIPA buffer before the addition of Laemmli sample buffer (24Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (205112) Google Scholar). Finally, samples were boiled for 5 min, loaded into pre-cast gels (Bio-Rad) for protein electrophoresis on a mini-protean III system (Bio-Rad), and subsequently transferred to nitrocellulose membrane. Ten percent precast gels were used except when Western blotting was conducted for c-Src from Cx43 IP samples, in which 7.5% precast gels were used to enhance the separation between Src and IgG heavy chain bands. Western blotting was conducted according to a protocol described previously (10Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 2644-2650Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Briefly, membranes were blocked in Tris-buffered saline solution containing 0.2% Tween 20 and 5% skim milk for an hour before the overnight incubation with a primary antibody and subsequent horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies. The membranes were washed and incubated for 1 min in an ECL solution (Amersham Biosciences) before x-ray film exposure and development. Triton X-100-soluble and -insoluble Fractionation—Confluent cultures of astrocytes were harvested in 1× phosphate-buffered saline (Cellgro) containing protease inhibitors and phosphatase inhibitors including sodium fluoride and sodium orthovanadate, sonicated, and centrifuged at 3,000 rpm for 15 min to obtain membrane-enriched pellet, which was subsequently resuspended by sonication in a RIPA buffer containing 1% Triton X-100. The samples were incubated for 30 min on ice and centrifuged for 30 min at 12,500 × g. The supernatant was collected and subjected to further centrifugation at 100,000 × g using a Ti-70 rotor in a Beckman ultracentrifuge for 50 min. The Triton-soluble supernatant was transferred to a fresh Eppendorf tube, whereas the Triton-insoluble pellet was rinsed three times using RIPA buffer containing 1% Triton X-100 and resuspended in the RIPA containing Nonidet P-40 and sodium deoxycholate by sonication. Ten percent of these two fractions was directly used for normal Western blotting analysis, and the rest was subjected to c-Src IP using the protocol described above. Immunofluorescence Staining—The immunostaining protocol was as described previously (10Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 2644-2650Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Primary astrocytes were plated on glass coverslips (Fisher) and allowed to grow to confluence before treatment to induce CIH. After CIH, cells were fixed using 4% paraformaldehyde and permeabilized using 0.3% Triton X-100 and incubated with primary antibodies overnight at 4 °C followed by incubation with the appropriate secondary antibodies conjugated with either Alexa488 or Alexa594 (Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR). Immunofluorescence images were acquired using a Nikon fluorescence microscope equipped with a Spot CCD camera (Diagnostic Instruments Inc., Sterling Heights, MI) or an Olympus FluoView500 confocal system (Melville, NY). Statistics—Western blots were quantified by measuring the relative density of protein bands recognized by a particular antibody using Scion Image software (Frederick, MD). A comparison between the values of control (set at 1 unless otherwise specified) and CIH samples was made and analyzed using the Student's t test. p values ≤0.05 were considered statistically significant between two groups. Induction of Cx43 Dephosphorylation by Intracellular Acidification—Because it has been shown that intracellular acidosis can enhance the binding of c-Src to Cx43 (19Duffy H.S. Ashton A.W. O'Donnell P. Coombs W. Taffet S.M. Delmar M. Spray D.C. Circ. Res. 2004; 94: 215-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar), we first used Western blotting to examine whether intracellular acidosis caused alterations in the phosphorylation state of Cx43. In non-stressed cells serine/threonine phosphorylation of Cx43 results in decreased mobility on SDS-PAGE and slower migrating bands usually appearing as a doublet that are commonly referred to as P1 and P2 (7Crow D.S. Beyer E.C. Paul D.L. Kobe S.S. Lau A.F. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 1754-1763Crossref PubMed Scopus (304) Google Scholar, 8Musil L.S. Cunningham B.A. Edelman G.M. Goodenough D.A. J. Cell Biol. 1990; 111: 2077-2088Crossref PubMed Scopus (592) Google Scholar, 9Laird D.W. Puranam K.L. Revel J.P. Biochem. J. 1991; 273: 67-72Crossref PubMed Scopus (396) Google Scholar). The fastest migrating form is usually referred to as P0 and represents non-phosphorylated newly synthesized or dephosphorylated Cx43 (7Crow D.S. Beyer E.C. Paul D.L. Kobe S.S. Lau A.F. Mol. Cell. Only occasionally, a so-called P′ form has observed between P1 and P0 (21Nagy J.I. Li W.E.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 4567-4572PubMed Google Scholar, 25Mikalsen S.O. Kaalhus O. J. Biol. Neurochem. 1994; 62: 2394-2403Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). In astrocytes, the majority of Cx43 protein is phosphorylated and migrates at about the 43-kDa level, whereas the non-phosphorylated or dephosphorylated form migrates at the 41-kDa level (10Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 2644-2650Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, 20Li W.E.I. Ochalski P.A. Hertzberg E.L. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurochem. 1994; 62: 2394-2403Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 27Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Neuroscience. 2000; 97: 113-123Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Under certain experimental interventions, the 41-kDa band increases with a proportional loss in P2 and P1, and this has been used as indication of dephosphorylation of Cx43 at serine/threonine residues (7Crow D.S. Beyer E.C. Paul D.L. Kobe S.S. Lau A.F. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 1754-1763Crossref PubMed Scopus (304) Google Scholar, 10Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 1998; 18: 2520-2537Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 26Hossain M.Z. Murphy L.J. Hertzberg E.L. Nagy J.I. J. Neurochem. 1994; 62: 2394-2403Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 28Cruciani V. Kaalhus O. Mikalsen S.O. Exp. Cell Res. 1999; 252: 449-463Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). In this study dephosphorylated Cx43 refers to the 41-kDa isoform of Cx43 that has reduced content of phosphate groups even though the exact phosphate content is not yet well defined. In cultured astrocytes this Cx43 isoform can be selectively recognized by antibody Zy13 (10Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 2644-2650Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 1A, when astrocytes were subjected to 30-min treatments, causing graded reduction of intracellular pH from 7.4 to 6.5, there was a gradual reduction of the 43-kDa phosphorylated form and a concomitant increase of the 41-kDa non-phosphorylated form, suggesting that intracellular acidosis caused dephosphorylation of Cx43. Consistent with our previous finding, c-Src antibody did not pull down significant amounts of Cx43 when astrocytes were maintained at neutral pH (Fig. 1B, lane 1). However, an intense Cx43 band was detected when astrocytes were held at pH 6.5 for 30 min (Fig. 1B, lane 2). Surprisingly, this Cx43 band migrated at the 41-kDa level, corresponding to the dephosphorylated form of Cx43. Because the 41-kDa form of Cx43 is also present in neutral pH samples but is apparently not associated with c-Src, this result suggests that intracellular acidosis induced a selective binding of c-Src to dephosphorylated Cx43. In this experiment astrocytes were exposed to solutions containing 145 mm KCl and nigericin, which causes a total collapse of the transmembrane potassium concentration gradient, a condition rarely seen in living cells. Thus, we further examined the relationship between changes in Cx43 phosphorylation state and Cx43/c-Src binding in astrocytes using an in vitro ischemia model, CIH, in which cell metabolism is inhibited by the addition of iodoacetate and cyanide. We and others have previously reported that CIH causes massive dephosphorylation of Cx43 in rat astrocytes (10Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 2644-2650Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, 22Cotrina M.L. Kang J. Lin J.H. Bueno E. Hansen T.W. He L. Liu Y. Nedergaard M. J. Neurosci. 1998; 18: 2520-2537Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Anti-Cx43 antibody 18A revealed an evident shift of the phosphorylated forms to the dephosphorylated form (Fig. 2A, both lanes). An increase of the 41-kDa band was clearly detected using monoclonal antibody Zy13 (Fig. 2B, both lanes) that we had previously demonstrated to preferentially detect the dephosphorylated form of Cx43 (10Li W.E.I. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 2644-2650Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, 20Li W.E.I. Ochalski P.A. Hertzberg E.L. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Nagy J.I. Eur. J. Neurosci. 2000; 12: 2644-2650Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). It is noteworthy that very little immunostaining was produced with antibody Zy13 in control astrocytes and that the marked increase in Cx43 immunostaining with this antibody after CIH occurred predominantly at the plasma membrane (Fig. 2, C4), suggesting that the CIH-induced dephosphorylation occurred mainly at sites where Cx43 formed gap junctions between astrocytes rather than in cytoplasmic locations. This change in phosphorylation coincided with a reduction of gap junctional coupling in CIH-treated astrocytes (Fig. 2D). Association of Cx43 with c-Src—To determine whether CIH also

To avoid detection and targeting by the immune system, the plague-causing bacterium Yersinia pestis uses a type III secretion system to deliver a set of inhibitory proteins into the cytoplasm of immune cells. One of these proteins is an exceptionally active tyrosine phosphatase termed YopH, which paralyzes lymphocytes and macrophages by dephosphorylating critical tyrosine kinases and signal transduction molecules. Because Y. pestis strains lacking YopH are avirulent, we set out to develop small molecule inhibitors for YopH. We used a novel and cost-effective approach, in which leads from a chemical library screening were analyzed and computationally docked into the crystal structure of YopH. This resulted in the identification of a series of novel YopH inhibitors with nanomolar Ki values, as well as the structural basis for inhibition. Our inhibitors lack the polar phosphate-mimicking moiety of rationally designed tyrosine phosphatase inhibitors, and they readily entered live cells and rescued them from YopH-induced tyrosine dephosphorylation, signaling paralysis, and cell death. These inhibitors may become useful for treating the lethal infection by Y. pestis. To avoid detection and targeting by the immune system, the plague-causing bacterium Yersinia pestis uses a type III secretion system to deliver a set of inhibitory proteins into the cytoplasm of immune cells. One of these proteins is an exceptionally active tyrosine phosphatase termed YopH, which paralyzes lymphocytes and macrophages by dephosphorylating critical tyrosine kinases and signal transduction molecules. Because Y. pestis strains lacking YopH are avirulent, we set out to develop small molecule inhibitors for YopH. We used a novel and cost-effective approach, in which leads from a chemical library screening were analyzed and computationally docked into the crystal structure of YopH. This resulted in the identification of a series of novel YopH inhibitors with nanomolar Ki values, as well as the structural basis for inhibition. Our inhibitors lack the polar phosphate-mimicking moiety of rationally designed tyrosine phosphatase inhibitors, and they readily entered live cells and rescued them from YopH-induced tyrosine dephosphorylation, signaling paralysis, and cell death. These inhibitors may become useful for treating the lethal infection by Y. pestis. To survive in humans, pathogenic bacteria have evolved numerous mechanisms to evade the immune response in the host (1Ernst J.D. Cell. Microbiol. 2000; 2: 379-386Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar, 2DeVinney I. Steele-Mortimer I. Finlay B.B. Trends Microbiol. 2000; 8: 29-33Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar). One of the most successful strategies was adopted by Yersinia pestis, namely a type III secretion system that injects a set of paralyzing proteins directly into the cytoplasm of macrophages and lymphocytes that the bacterium encounters in the lymph nodes of infected individuals (3Persson C. Nordfelth R. Holmstrom A. Hakansson S. Rosqvist R. Wolf-Watz H. Mol. Microbiol. 1995; 18: 135-150Crossref PubMed Scopus (207) Google Scholar, 4Cheng L.W. Schneewind O. J. Bacteriol. 2000; 182: 3183-3190Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). As a result, the targeted cells become unable to respond, and the bacteria can multiply unopposed by the normal mechanisms of host defense.The natural route of Y. pestis infection is by transmission from infected rats or other animals by blood-sucking fleas, which are weakened by the bacteria in their gut and therefore expel bacterial mass into the epidermis of their next victim when trying to feed (5Titball R.W. Leary S.E. Br. Med. Bull. 1998; 54: 625-633Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar, 6Hinnebusch B.J. J. Mol. Med. 1997; 75: 645-652Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). From these flea bites, the bacteria travel to local lymph nodes (7Autenrieth I.B. Vogel U. Preger S. Heymer B. Heesemann J. Infect. Immun. 1993; 61: 2585-2595Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 8Autenrieth I.B. Hantschmann P. Heymer B. Heesemann J. Immunobiology. 1993; 187: 1-16Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 9Autenrieth I.B. Firsching R. J. Med. Microbiol. 1996; 44: 285-294Crossref PubMed Scopus (154) Google Scholar), where they multiply and cause a massive lymphadenitis within 2–6 days (5Titball R.W. Leary S.E. Br. Med. Bull. 1998; 54: 625-633Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). These enlarged and painful lymph nodes, or “bubos,” give the disease its common name Bubonic Plague. Unless treated with high dose streptomycin- or tetracycline-type antibiotics during the first few days, the infection develops into a toxemic sepsis, which is often fatal (5Titball R.W. Leary S.E. Br. Med. Bull. 1998; 54: 625-633Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar, 6Hinnebusch B.J. J. Mol. Med. 1997; 75: 645-652Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). A normally very rare, but much more rapidly lethal, form of the infection is caused by inhaled bacteria and is referred to as pneumonic plague or plague pneumonia (10Cleri D.J. Vernaleo J.R. Lombardi L.J. Rabbat M.S. Mathew A. Marton R. Reyelt M.C. Semin. Respir. Infect. 1997; 12: 12-23PubMed Google Scholar). By this route of infection, the number of bacteria entering the body can be much larger than from microscopic flea bites, and the bacteria are efficiently disseminated to the peritracheal, mediastinal, and other central lymph nodes, from which they gain access to the bloodstream much earlier. Although several vaccines exist (11Titball R.W. Williamson E.D. Vaccine. 2001; 19: 4175-4184Crossref PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar, 12Friedlander A.M. Welkos S.L. Worsham P.L. Andrews G.P. Heath D.G. Anderson Jr., G.W. Pitt M.L. Estep J. Davis K. Clin. Infect. Dis. 1995; 21: 178-181Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar), and Yersinia usually is sensitive to antibiotics, the pneumonic form of the disease is difficult to diagnose and still often results in death (10Cleri D.J. Vernaleo J.R. Lombardi L.J. Rabbat M.S. Mathew A. Marton R. Reyelt M.C. Semin. Respir. Infect. 1997; 12: 12-23PubMed Google Scholar).Despite efforts to eradicate the disease, natural reservoirs of Y. pestis still exist in wild rats and other rodent populations in parts of Africa, southeast Asia, and southwestern United States (13Christie A.B. Ecol. Dis. 1982; 1: 111-115PubMed Google Scholar), and sporadic human cases of plague still occur every year. Although these cases pale by comparison to the devastating pandemics that killed an estimated 200 million people, mostly in Europe, during historical times (5Titball R.W. Leary S.E. Br. Med. Bull. 1998; 54: 625-633Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar, 6Hinnebusch B.J. J. Mol. Med. 1997; 75: 645-652Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar), the World Health Organization now recognizes plague as a reemerging public health concern. There are also increasing fears that Y. pestis may be used for biological warfare or bioterrorism (14McGovern T.W. Christopher G.W. Eitzen E.M. Arch. Dermatol. 1999; 135: 311-322Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 15Inglesby T.V. Dennis D.T. Henderson D.A. Bartlett J.G. Ascher M.S. Eitzen E. Fine A.D. Friedlander A.M. Hauer J. Koerner J.F. Layton M. McDade J. Osterholm M.T. O'Toole T. Parker G. Perl T.M. Russell P.K. Schoch-Spana M. Tonat K. J. Am. Med. Recombinant CD45, PTP1B, and LAR were purchased from BIOMOL Research Laboratories.Chemical Library Screening for YopH Inhibitors—A subset of 10,000 compounds from the DIVERSet™ library of 50,000 drug-like molecules (ChemBridge, Inc.) was screened in a 96-well format in vitro assay. Each reaction contained 50 nm YopH, 1 mmpNPP, and 0.03 mg/ml compound in 0.1 m BisTris, pH 6.0, reaction buffer. The final volume amounted to 50 μl and contained 2% Me2SO. The reaction was initiated by addition of pNPP after a preincubation of the enzyme with the compounds for 10 min at room temperature. After 7 min, the reaction was quenched by addition of 100 μl of BIOMOL GREEN™ reagent, and the pNPP hydrolysis was determined by measuring the absorbance of the complexed free phosphate at 620 nm. The nonenzymatic hydrolysis of the substrate was corrected by measuring the control without addition of enzyme. To quantitate the inhibitory efficacy of the library compounds, we determined the ratio of inhibition in comparison to 200 μm orthovanadate, a PTP inhibitor. Every compound with a ratio of >1 was considered as a hit. ClogP for each compound was calculated with ChemDraw8.Ki Determination—The YopH PTP-catalyzed hydrolysis of pNPP in the presence of inhibitors was assayed at 30 °C in 0.1 m BisTris, pH 6.0, assay buffer containing 1 mm dithiothreitol and 5% Me2SO. The ionic strength was adjusted to 150 mm with NaCl. The enzyme was preincubated with various fixed concentrations of inhibitors for 10 min. The reaction was initiated by the addition of various concentrations of pNPP (ranging from 0.2 to 10 Km) to the reaction mixtures to a final volume of 100 μl. The reaction was quenched by addition of 100 μl of 1 m NaOH. The nonenzymatic hydrolysis of the substrate was corrected by measuring the control without addition of enzyme. The amount of product p-nitrophenol was determined from the absorbance at 405 nm detected by a PowerWaveX340 microplate spectrophotometer (Bio-Tek Instruments, Inc.) using a molar extinction coefficient of 18,000 m-1 cm-1. The inhibition constant and inhibition pattern were evaluated by fitting the data to the Michaelis-Menten equations for either competitive (Equation 1), uncompetitive (Equation 2), or mixed (Equation 3) inhibition, using nonlinear regression and the program GraphPad Prism® (version 4.0).v0=Vmax[S]/(Km(app)+[S]) with Km(app)=Km(1+[I]/Ki) (Eq. 1) v0=Vmax[S]/(Km+(1+[I]/Ki)[S]) with Km(app)=Km/(1+[I]/Ki)(Eq. 2) v0=Vmax[S]/((1+[I]/Kic)Km+(1+[I]/Kiu)[S]) with Km(app)=Km(1+[I]/Kic)/(1+[I]/Kiu)(Eq. 3) In the case of the mixed inhibition model, Kic is the inhibition constant for the competitive participation, and Kiu is the inhibition constant for the uncompetitive participation. For a comparison of the fitting results, the second-order Akaike's Information Criterion (AICc) was calculated with Equation 4, where N is the number of data points, SS the absolute sum of squares, and K the number of parameters fit by nonlinear regression plus 1.AICc=Nln(SS/N)+2K+(2K(K+1))/(N−K−1)(Eq. 4) The probability to have chosen the right model can be computed by Equation 5, where Δ is the difference between Akaike's Information Criterion (AICc) scores.probability=exp(−0.5Δ)/(1+exp(−0.5Δ))(Eq. 5) IC50 Measurements—The PTP-catalyzed hydrolysis of pNPP in the presence of inhibitor was assayed at 30 °C in a 100-μl reaction system in the same assay buffer described above. At various concentrations of the compound, the initial rate at fixed pNPP concentrations (equal to the corresponding Km values for each PTP) was measured by determining the free phosphate with the BIOMOL GREEN™ reagent, as described above. The IC50 value was determined by plotting the relative pNPP activity versus inhibitor concentration and fitting to Equation 6 using GraphPad Prism®.Vi/V0=IC50/(IC50+[I])(Eq. 6) In this case, Vi is the reaction velocity when the inhibitor concentration is [I]; V0 is the reaction velocity with no inhibitor, and IC50 = Ki + Ki[S]/Km.Molecular Modeling—Molecular modeling studies were conducted on several R12000 SGI Octane workstations with the software package Sybyl version 6.9 (TRIPOS). Energy-minimized molecular models of the compounds were generated by the Sybyl/MAXIMIN2 routine. Flexible ligand docking calculations were performed with FlexX as implemented in Sybyl. For each compound, 20 solutions were generated and rank-ordered via FlexX score and CSCORE. In all cases, there was a high degree of convergence for the salicylic acid-furanyl moiety and more variability in the position of the remaining molecules. The coordinates of three-dimensional structure of catalytic domain of YopH (Protein Data Bank codes 1YTS and 1QZ0) were used in the docking studies, and the binding pocket was defined as composed of the following amino acid residues: Arg-205, Arg-228, Phe-229, Ile-232, Asn-245, Ala-258, Cys-259, Gln-260, Tyr-261, Val-284, Leu-285, Ala-286, Ser-287, Glu-290, Ile-291, Phe-296, Met-298, Val-351, Trp-354, Pro-355, Asp-356, Gln-357, Thr-358, Ala-359, Val-360, Ile-401, His-402, Ser-403 (Cys-403 in wild-type YopH), Arg-404, Ala-405, Gly-406, Val-407, Gly-408, Arg-409, Thr-410, Ala-411, Gln-412, Leu-413, Ile-414, Arg-440, Asn-441, Ile-443, Met-444, Val-445, Gln-446, Lys-447, and Gln-450. Molecular surfaces were generated with MOLCAD as implemented in Sybyl. Comparisons with other PTPs were made by using the x-ray coordinates for PTP1B (Protein Data Bank code 1PA1), VHR (Protein Data Bank code 1VHR), and bovine LMPTPB (1DG9) and the computer models of the membrane-proximal domains of CD45, VHX, and HePTP. These were generated as described (50Alonso A. Sasin J. Bottini N. Friedberg I. Friedberg I. Osterman A. Godzik A. Hunter T. Dixon J.E. Mustelin T. Monocytes/macrophages were eliminated by adherence to plastic for 1 h at 37 °C. Jurkat T leukemia cells were kept at logarithmic growth in RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum, 2 mm l-glutamine, 1 mm sodium pyruvate, nonessential amino acids, and 100 units/ml each of penicillin G and streptomycin. For T cell receptor- and CD28-induced tyrosine phosphorylation responses, normal T lymphocytes were incubated in ice for 15 min with 10 μg/ml OKT3 and anti-CD28 mAbs, washed, and incubated with a cross-linking rabbit anti-mouse Ig for 15 min, washed, and transferred to 37 °C for 5 min. Cells were pelleted and lysed in 20 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl, 5 mm EDTA containing 1% Nonidet P-40, 1 mm Na3VO4, 10 μg/ml aprotinin and leupeptin, 100 μg/ml soybean trypsin inhibitor, and 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride and clarified by centrifugation at 15,000 rpm for 20 min. Lysate was mixed with an equal volume of twice concentrated SDS sample buffer, boiled for 1 min, and resolved by SDS-PAGE.SDS-PAGE and Immunoblotting—These procedures were done as before (39Alonso A. Results are given as pg/ml of secreted interleukin-2/2 × 105 cells.RESULTSIdentification of Lead Compounds by Chemical Library Screening—A 96-well format in vitro assay was used to screen the first 10,000 compounds of the DIVERSet™ library (ChemBridge, Inc.) of drug-like compounds. A total of 10 compounds inhibited YopH to a higher extent than 200 μm orthovanadate, a general PTP inhibitor. After determination of the kinetic parameters of these 10 first hits, we selected four compounds, which were showing a competitive or mixed inhibition pattern with a Ki value <10 μm, for closer inspection. Two of these, a quinone and a charged thio-imidazole, were subsequently discarded, and we focused on a 5-methylenethiazolidine-2,4-dione linked via a furanyl ring to a salicylic acid (compound 1) and a 5-methylene-2-thioxothiazolidin-4-one (additionally substituted at the nitrogen atom) similarly linked via a furanyl ring to a nitrophenol (compound 2). These two inhibited YopH with competitive Ki values of 0.311 ± 0.053 and 1.87 ± 0.924 μm, respectively, and were relatively selective for YopH (Table I). The structures of compounds 1 and 2 are shown in Table II. These two represent our initial hits from the chemical library screen.Table ISelectivity of initial hit compounds 1 and 2Compound 1 IC50Compound 2 IC50Compound 1-fold IC50Compound 2-fold IC50μmμmYopH0.393.911CD458.6392210PTP 1B12393110VHX1020265.1VHR28497213HePTP>100>100>256>26LMPTP B>100>100>256>26VH1>100>100>256>26LAR>100>100>256>26 Open table in a new tab Table IIKinetic data of 2 initial hits and 21 representative analogs Open table in a new tab Structure-Activity Relationship Analysis of Compound 1 and 2—Encouraged by these findings, we investigated the structure-activity relationships for a total of 61 analogs that all contained a substituted phenyl ring linked via a furanyl moiety to a more diverse entity at the other end of the molecule, preferentially a 5-methylenethiazolidine ring. A total of 44 compounds inhibited YopH in a competitive manner with Ki values of <100 μm. The structures and kinetic data for a representative set of 21 analogs are given in Table II. Significantly, 13 of the 16 salicylic acid analogs were among the 26 best compounds (competitive inhibition with Ki values <10 μm). Elimination of the salicylic acid moiety (compound 23) led to a complete loss of YopH inhibition, whereas salicyl furyl aldehyde (compound 13) shows good competitive inhibition (Ki = 2.08 μm). However, salicylic acid alone was a poor inhibitor (Ki = 882 μm) compared with the most potent inhibitor, compound 3, which has a 6,211-fold lower inhibitory constant (Ki = 0.143 μm). The very similar compound 7, which only differs in the location of a single methyl group, shows almost 10 times less activity, suggesting some steric constraints for the putative binding site or some very specific interactions of that methyl group. A comparison of the Ki values for compounds 12 and 20, which differ by a methyl group in a very similar position, supports the latter.Another example of a unique binding mode is presented by the second best inhibitor, compound 4 (Ki = 0.208 μm). In this case, the structurally very similar compound 18 (Ki = 6.60 μm), in which the positions of the carboxylic and the hydroxyl groups have been switched, has a 32 times higher Ki value, supporting the notion of specific binding.Substitution of the hydroxyl group in the original hit compound 1 by a chlorine in compound 16 led to a 14.5 times less inhibitory activity. Elimin

Lysophosphatidic acid (LPA) protects epithelial and fibroblast cell lines from apoptosis. In B-cells, LPA acts as a growth factor promoting cell proliferation. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is characterized by the accumulation of CD19+/CD5+ B-lymphocytes primarily through a block in apoptosis. The mechanisms underlying this defect are not fully understood. We investigated whether LPA could be a survival factor in CLL cells. Herein, we demonstrate that LPA protects B-cell lines BJAB and I-83 and primary CLL cells but not normal B-cells from fludarabine- and etoposide-induced apoptosis. Furthermore, LPA prevented spontaneous apoptosis in primary CLL cells. The LPA1 expression was found to be increased in primary CLL cells compared with normal B-cells correlating with LPA prevention of apoptosis. Treatment of primary CLL cells with the LPA receptor antagonist, diacylglycerol pyrophosphate, reverses the protective effect of LPA against apoptosis, and down-regulation of the LPA1 by siRNA blocked LPA-mediated protection against spontaneous apoptosis in primary CLL cells. The protective effect of LPA was inhibited by blocking activation of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase/AKT signaling pathway. These results indicate that LPA is a survival factor in B-cell lines and primary CLL cells but not normal B-cells. Thus, drugs targeting the LPA receptors might be an effective therapy against B-cell-derived malignancies such as CLL. Furthermore, LPA prevented spontaneous apoptosis in primary CLL cells. The LPA1 expression was found to be increased in primary CLL cells compared with normal B-cells correlating with LPA prevention of apoptosis. Treatment of primary CLL cells with the LPA receptor antagonist, diacylglycerol pyrophosphate, reverses the protective effect of LPA against apoptosis, and down-regulation of the LPA1 by siRNA blocked LPA-mediated protection against spontaneous apoptosis in primary CLL cells. The protective effect of LPA was inhibited by blocking activation of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase/AKT signaling pathway. These results indicate that LPA is a survival factor in B-cell lines and primary CLL cells but not normal B-cells. Acta. 2002; 1582: 257-264Crossref PubMed Scopus (243) Google Scholar, 2Swarthout J.T. Walling H.W. Cell Mol. Life Sci. 2000; 57: 1978-1985Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). LPA also possesses a range of biological activities similar to growth factors. These include stimulation of cellular proliferation, platelet aggregation, smooth muscle cell contraction, and tumor cell invasion (3Mills G.B. Moolenaar W.H. Nat. Rev. Cancer. 2003; 3: 582-591Crossref PubMed Scopus (949) Google Scholar). In B-cells, LPA acts as a growth factor increasing cell proliferation, intracellular calcium, and immunoglobulin formation. In addition, LPA protects ovarian cancer cells against chemotherapeutic drug-induced apoptosis and prevents apoptosis in serum-deprived renal proximal tubular cells, fibroblasts, macrophages, T cells, and Schwann cells, indicating that like growth factors, LPA acts as a general survival factor (4Fang X. Yu S. LaPushin R. Lu Y. Furui T. Penn L.Z. Stokoe D. Erickson J.R. Bast Jr., R.C. Mills G.B. Biochem. J. 2000; 352: 135-143Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar, 5Goetzl E.J. Lee H. Dolezalova H. Kalli K.R. Conover C.A. Hu Y.L. Azuma T. Stossel T.P. Karliner J.S. Jaffe R.B. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 2000; 905: 177-187Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar, 6Weiner J.A. Chun J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 5233-5238Crossref PubMed Scopus (226) Google Scholar, 7Ye X. Ishii I. Kingsbury M.A. Chun J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2002; 1585: 108-113Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar). LPA can also effectively block death receptor-induced apoptosis (8Kang Y.C. Kim K.M. Lee K.S. Namkoong S. Lee S.J. Han J.A. Jeoung D. Ha K.S. Kwon Y.G. Kim Y.M. Cell Death Differ. 2004; 11: 1287-1298Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). The ability of LPA to act as a survival factor in B-cell malignancies is unknown. LPA promotes cell survival through receptor-mediated signaling pathways. LPA activates a serine threonine kinase AKT/PKB (AKT), leading to inactivation of pro-apoptotic proteins, such as BAD, or activation of transcription factors that increase the expression of anti-apoptotic proteins (9Baudhuin L.M. Cristina K.L. Lu J. Xu Y. Mol. Pharmacol. 2002; 62: 660-671Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar, 10Deng W. Wang D.A. Gosmanova E. Johnson L.R. Tigyi G. Am. J. Physiol. 2003; 284: G821-G829Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). In ovarian cancer cell lines and HeLa cells, LPA protection against apoptosis is mediated by the AKT signaling pathway (11Frankel A. Mills G.B. Clin. Cancer Res. 1996; 2: 1307-1313PubMed Google Scholar). In contrast, LPA protection against apoptosis in fibroblast cells is mediated by the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling pathway (12Fang X. Yu S. Bast R.C. Liu S. Xu H.-J. Hu S.-X. LaPushin R. Claret F.X. Aggarwal B.B. Lu Y. Mills G.B. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 9653-9661Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). In addition, LPA activates transcription factors, such as NFκB, that can lead to increased expression of anti-apoptotic proteins and cell survival (13Palmetshofer A. Robson S.C. Nehls V. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1999; 82: 1532-1537Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar, 14Shahrestanifar M. Fan X. Manning D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 3828-3833Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). Thus, LPA binding with its cognate receptors activates many anti-apoptotic signaling pathways. LPA is present in the plasma bound to albumin (2Swarthout J.T. Walling H.W. Cell Mol. Life Sci. 2000; 57: 1978-1985Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). Similar to LPA receptors, LPA levels are often increased in ascites and the plasma of ovarian cancer patients and in the plasma of patients with multiple myeloma (1Fang X. Schummer M. Mao M. Yu S. Tabassam F.H. Swaby R. Hasegawa Y. Tanyi J.L. LaPushin R. Eder A. Jaffe R. Erickson J. Mills G.B. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2002; 1582: 257-264Crossref PubMed Scopus (243) Google Scholar, 15Sasagawa T. Okita M. Murakami J. Kato T. Watanabe A. Lipids. 1999; 34: 17-21Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). Ovarian cancer cells produce LPA in significant amounts compared with normal ovarian epithelial cells, which could explain the increased LPA in the ascitic fluid of ovarian cancer patients (16Xu Y. Fang X.J. Casey G. Mills G.B. Biochem. J. 1995; 309: 933-940Crossref PubMed Scopus (252) Google Scholar). The elevated levels of LPA have been suggested to contribute to tumor invasiveness, proliferation, and resistance to apoptosis (3Mills G.B. Moolenaar W.H. Nat. Rev. Cancer. 2003; 3: 582-591Crossref PubMed Scopus (949) Google Scholar). Four specific G protein-coupled receptors of LPA have been identified: LPA1 (Edg-2), LPA2 (Edg-4), LPA3 (Edg-7), and LPA4 (17Anliker B. Chun J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 20555-20558Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar, 18Fukushima N. Chun J. Prostaglandins Other Lipid Mediat. 2001; 64: 21-32Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar). The LPA1 receptor is the most widely expressed receptor, whereas LPA2, LPA3, and LPA4 have more restricted expression patterns (17Anliker B. Chun J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 20555-20558Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar, 18Fukushima N. Chun J. Prostaglandins Other Lipid Mediat. 2001; 64: 21-32Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar). Mice lacking LPA1 show failure to suckle leading to neonatal mortality (19Contos J.J. Fukushima N. Weiner J.A. Kaushal D. Chun J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 13384-13389Crossref PubMed Scopus (426) Google Scholar). In contrast, mice lacking LPA2 show no obvious phenotypic deficiencies, indicating a redundancy in LPA receptor functionality (18Fukushima N. Chun J. Prostaglandins Other Lipid Mediat. 2001; 64: 21-32Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar). In addition, LPA1 expression is increased in colon cancer cells, and LPA2 and LPA3 are elevated in ovarian cancer cells, suggesting that LPA receptors are involved in tumorigenesis (20Fang X. Gaudette D. Furui T. Mao M. Estrella V. Eder A. Pustilnik T. Sasagawa T. Lapushin R. Yu S. Jaffe R.B. Wiener J.R. Erickson J.R. Mills G.B. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 2000; 905: 188-208Crossref PubMed Scopus (218) Google Scholar, 21Shida D. Kitayama J. Yamaguchi H. Okaji Y. Tsuno N.H. Watanabe T. Takuwa Y. Nagawa H. Cancer Res. 2003; 63: 1706-1711PubMed Google Scholar). Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is the most common form of adult leukemia and is characterized by the accumulation of CD19+/CD5+ B-lymphocytes in the peripheral blood, bone marrow, and lymphoid organs (22Bannerji R. Byrd J.C. Curr. Opin. Oncol. 2000; 12: 22-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 23Caligaris-Cappio F. Hamblin T.J. J. Clin. Oncol. 1999; 17: 399-408Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 24Johnston J.B. Greer J.P. Foerster J. Lukens J. Paraskevas F. Rodgers G.M. Glader B.E. Wintrobe's Clinical Hematology. 11th Ed. Williams & Wilkins, Baltimore, MD2003: 2429-2463Google Scholar). This is achieved primarily through a block in apoptosis. The increased cell survival is due in part to increased expression of anti-apoptotic proteins such as Bcl-2 and the survival signals delivered by extracellular factors from “nurse-like,” fibroblast, stromal, or follicular dendritic cells (25Bernal A. Pastore R.D. Asgary Z. Keller S.A. Cesarman E. Liou H.C. Schattner E.J. Blood. 2001; 98: 3050-3057Crossref PubMed Scopus (154) Google Scholar, 26Burger J.A. Tsukada N. Burger M. Zvaifler N.J. Dell'Aquila M. Kipps T.J. Blood. 2000; 96: 2655-2663Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 27Pedersen I.M. Kitada S. Leoni L.M. Zapata J.M. Karras J.G. Tsukada N. Kipps T.J. Choi Y.S. Bennett F. Reed J.C. Blood. 2002; 100: 1795-1801Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar, 28Rai K.R. Peterson B.L. Appelbaum F.R. Kolitz J. Elias L. Shepherd L. Hines J. Threatte G.A. Larson R.A. Cheson B.D. Schiffer C.A. N. Engl. J. Med. 2000; 343: 1750-1757Crossref PubMed Scopus (903) Google Scholar). However, these survival responses cannot fully explain the accumulation of CLL cells, because CLL cells have varying levels of Bcl-2 family members and circulate without constant contact with survival-mediating cells. Indeed, CLL cells survive for a prolonged length of time in vitro in the presence of plasma from CLL patients, compared with CLL cells cultured in serum-free medium. Plasma albumin that binds to lipids has been shown to provide a survival signal to CLL cells by activating AKT, but the mechanism of this survival signal is not well understood (29Jones D.T. Ganeshaguru K. Anderson R.J. Jackson T.R. Bruckdorfer K.R. Low S.Y. Palmqvist L. Prentice H.G. Hoffbrand A.V. Mehta A.B. Wickremasinghe R.G. Blood. 2003; 101: 3174-3180Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). Herein we have demonstrated for the first time that LPA protects primary CLL cells and BJAB (a B-cell Burkitt lymphoma) and I-83 (B-CLL-like) cell lines from spontaneous, fludarabine (Flu), chlorambucil (CLB), or etoposide (Et)-induced apoptosis. LPA1 is expressed at higher levels in primary CLL cells as compared with normal B-cells. Blocking LPA binding to its receptors with a selective antagonist (DGPP) or inhibiting LPA1 expression blocked the inhibiting effects of LPA on apoptosis. Finally, this protection against apoptosis is mediated by the PI-3K/AKT signaling pathway. These results indicate that LPA is a survival factor for primary CLL cells. Materials—LPA (18:1, 18:0, and 16:0) and DGPP were purchased from Avanti Inc. and dissolved in phosphate-buffered saline containing 0.1% fatty acid-free bovine serum albumen. Unless otherwise stated 18:1 LPA was used in all experiments. Anti-phospho-AKT was purchased from Cell Signaling Inc. Anti-AKT antibodies and anti-actin antibodies were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology. Anti-LPA1 antibodies was purchased from Exalpha Biologicals Inc. Flu and Et were purchased from Sigma and dissolved in Me2SO. CLB was purchased from Sigma and dissolved in acidified ethanol containing 1% HCl. U0126 was purchased from Upstate Biotechnology, Inc., and LY294002 was purchased from Sigma. Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) was purchased from Sigma. Patients and Lymphocyte Isolation—Peripheral blood samples were obtained from normal individuals and CLL patients following informed consent in agreement with the Research Ethics Board at the University of Manitoba. The diagnosis of CLL was made by peripheral blood morphology and immunophenotyping, and the cells were CD19+, CD5+, and CD23+. In total 25 patient samples were obtained from patients with an average age of 66 years and an average lymphocyte count of 81 × 109 cells/liter. There were 17 males and eight females. There were four patients at Rai stage 0, four patients at Rai stage I, seven patients at Rai stage II, four patients at Rai stage III, and six patients at Rai stage IV. Upon receiving the blood samples, mononuclear cells were isolated from the buffy coat using a Ficoll-Paque density gradient, as we have described previously (30Begleiter A. Verburg L. Ashique A. Lee K. Israels L.G. Mowat M.R. Johnston J.B. Leukemia. 1995; 9: 1875-1881PubMed Google Scholar). The plasma was removed and stored at -20 °C for future experiments. The cell isolates were washed with ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4) and a second wash with ice-cold 10 mm Tris, 140 mm NH4Cl to lyse residual erythrocytes. When the peripheral blood lymphocyte counts were <30 × 109/liter, contaminating monocytes were removed from the isolates using CD33 antibodies coupled to magnetic beads and T cells removed by sheep red cell rosetting, as described previously (30Begleiter A. Verburg L. Ashique A. Lee K. Israels L.G. Mowat M.R. Johnston J.B. Leukemia. 1995; 9: 1875-1881PubMed Google Scholar). This recovers B-cells only from either CLL patients or normal volunteers. Cell Culture and Treatment Conditions—Lymphocytes were cultured at 37 °C in a humidified, 5% CO2 incubator at an initial density of 1 × 106 cells/ml in serum-free RPMI 1640 culture medium. BJAB and I-83 cells were also grown in RPMI 1640 supplemented with 100 units of penicillin, 100 μg streptomycin, and 10% fetal bovine serum. F-ara-A was used for these in vitro experiments, because Flu requires dephosphorylation to F-ara-A for activity, and this normally occurs rapidly in the plasma following clinical administration. For consistency, we will use the abbreviation Flu to denote F-ara-A treatment. The cells were incubated with or without Flu, CLB, or Et, in combination with varying concentrations of LPA. The cells were always incubated in serum-free conditions 24 h prior to treatment. Caspase Assay—The cells (1–2 × 106) were treated with 2.5 μm Flu, 10 μm LPA, or in combination. The cells were then lysed in caspase lysis buffer (10 mm HEPES, pH 7.4, 2 mm EDTA, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 1% Nonidet P-40, 2 mg/ml aprotinin, 10 μm leupectin, 10 μm pepstatin A, and 200 μm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) and centrifuged at 8000 × g for 5 min. 100 mg of protein was added to caspase reaction buffer (100 mm HEPES, pH 7.4, 20% glycerol, 5 mm dithiothreitol, and 0.5 mm EDTA) and 100 μm of the peptide Ac-DEVD-pNA (Biomol, Plymouth Meeting, PA). This was incubated at 37 °C in the dark for 4 h and read at 405-nm wavelength on a spectrophotometer. Reaction buffer and peptide without lysate was used as a control. Annexin V/7-AAD Staining—Cells (5 × 106) were collected in 5-ml tubes, centrifuged, and resuspended in 1× binding buffer (10 mm HEPES/NaOH, pH 7.4, 140 mm NaCl, 2.5 mm CaCl2), supplemented with annexin V-fluorescein isothiocyanate (BD PharMingen, Mississauga, ON) and 2.5 μg of 7-AAD (Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR). After 15 min of incubation at room temperature in the dark, an excess of 1× binding buffer was added to a final volume of 500 μl. The cells were then analyzed with a FACSCalibur flow cytometer (Becton-Dickinson, San Jose, CA). Acridine Orange/Ethidium Bromide Staining—The cells were resuspended in 100 μl of medium by gentle mixing and stained with a mixture of acridine orange (100 μg/ml) and ethidium bromide (100 μg/ml) in phosphate-buffered saline. A cell suspension was then applied onto a microscope slide and covered with a coverslip, and the cells were viewed using a fluorescence microscope with a fluorescein filter set to quantitate condensed DNA in apoptotic cells. Random fields were scored, and the percentage of apoptotic cells was determined from cells containing normal DNA to cells with condensed DNA. At least 200 cells were counted for each condition tested. Statistical significance was determined using a t test method. Western Blot Analysis—The cells were lysed in Nonidet P-40 lysis buffer (50 mm HEPES, pH 7.25, 150 mm NaCl, 50 μm ZnCl2,50 μm NaF, 2 mm EDTA, 1 mm sodium vanadate, 1.0% Nonidet P-40, 2 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride). The cell debris was removed by centrifugation at 13,000 × g for 5 min, and the protein concentration was determined by the Bradford assay. After SDS-PAGE, the proteins were transferred to nitrocellulose membranes. The membranes were blocked with 10% milk in Tris-buffered saline-Tween 20 solution. The blots were performed as described previously (31Gibson E.M. Henson E.S. Haney N. Villanueva J. Gibson S.B. Cancer Res. 2002; 62: 488-496PubMed Google Scholar). The blots were stripped in 10% SDS buffer and reprobed for β-actin to normalize for protein loaded in each lane. Electroporation—BJAB cells were transferred to fresh medium 24 h prior to transfection. The cells were collected by centrifugation and resuspended in RPMI medium at 2.5 × 107 cells/ml. The cells were then put on ice for 10 min, and 5 μg of plasmid was added into the bottom of the electroporation cuvette (0.4-cm gap; Bio-Rad). BJAB cells (0.4 ml) were added to the cuvette, and the cuvette was placed on ice for 10 min. The cuvette was then placed into an electroporation device and electroporated at 310 V, 10-ms pulse length, and 1 pulse with no intervals. The cuvette was then placed on ice for 10 min. The electroporated cells were then transferred to 10 ml of RPMI (10% fetal bovine serum) medium. Transfection of Primary CLL Cells with siRNA—Primary CLL cells were suspended in 12-well plates at 8.0 × 105 cells/well. 2 μg of siRNA against LPA1 (5′-r(CCGCCGCUUCCAUUUUUCCU)d(TT)-3′ and 5′-r(AGGAAAAAUGGAAGCGGCGGG)d(TT)-3′) and scrambled siRNA (5′-r(UUCUCCGAACGUGUUCACGU)d(TT)-3′ and 5′-r(ACGUGACACGUUCGGAGAA)d(TT)-3′) was diluted into 100 ml of medium. 12 μlof RNAiFect Transfection reagent (Qiagen) was added to the siRNA and incubated at room temperature for 10 min. The formed complexes between the reagent and siRNA were then added dropwise to the cells. The cells were then incubated with the transfection complexes under normal tissue culture conditions overnight. The next day the medium was changed to serum-free medium, and the cells were then treated with 5 μm LPA. After 24 h, the amount of cell death was determined by annexin V staining as described above. Transfection of HEK293 Cells—The cells were grown to ∼50% confluency and transfected with 5 μg of cDNA for human LPA1 in pcDNA3 vector (kind gift from Dr. Frank Fang, Virginia Commonwealth University) containing a FLAG tag. Transfections were performed using Lipofectamine as described in the manufacturer's instructions. After 24 h, the cells were treated with 100 μm Et for an additional 24 h. The cells were then cytospun and stained with antibodies against FLAG and Hoechst stain. The number of apoptotic cells was determined by chromatin condensation. Reverse Transcription (RT)-PCR for LPA1 mRNA—RT-PCR was performed using specific primers for human LPA1 (5′-CCACCTTCAGGCAGATCCTGTGT-3′ and 5′-AGGCAGAGCGGTCAGAGCCTT-3′). Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase primers were used for equal loading of mRNA. Amplification was performed using SuperScript One-step RT-PCR (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Thermal cycling was as follows: 30 min at 50 °C, 2 min at 95 °C, 40 cycles of 30 s at 95 °C, 1 min at 60 °C, and 1 min at 75 °C. One μg of RNA was used in the PCR. LPA Protects B-cell Lines from Chemotherapeutic Drug-induced Apoptosis—LPA has previously been shown to protect ovarian cancer cells from cisplatin- and taxol-induced apoptosis (11Frankel A. Mills G.B. Clin. Cancer Res. 1996; 2: 1307-1313PubMed Google Scholar, 20Fang X. Gaudette D. Furui T. Mao M. Estrella V. Eder A. Pustilnik T. Sasagawa T. Lapushin R. Yu S. Jaffe R.B. Wiener J.R. Erickson J.R. Mills G.B. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 2000; 905: 188-208Crossref PubMed Scopus (218) Google Scholar). We investigated here whether LPA can protect leukemic B-cell lines from chemotherapy-induced apoptosis. The Burkitt lymphoma cell line, BJAB, was treated with 2.5 μm Flu, 1.0 μm Et, or 2.5 μm CLB alone or with 10 μm LPA for 24 h. Et, Flu, and CLB induced 41, 45, and 45% apoptosis in BJAB cells, respectively (Fig. 1A). In combination with LPA, Et-induced apoptosis was reduced to 22%, Flu-induced apoptosis was reduced to 26%, and CLB-induced apoptosis was reduced to 19%. LPA alone did not affect cell survival (17% apoptotic cells; Fig. 1A). The CLL-like B-cell line, I-83, was also treated with Et, Flu, and CLB alone or in combination with LPA. Similar to BJAB cells, Et, Flu, and CLB induced 62, 47, and 34% apoptosis, respectively (Fig. 1A). In combination with LPA, Et-induced apoptosis was reduced to 48%, Flu-induced apoptosis was reduced to 34%, and CLB-induced apoptosis was reduced to 21%. In addition to B-cell lines, the Burkitt lymphoma T cell line, MOLT-4, was also protected by LPA from Flu-induced apoptosis; Flu induced 36% apoptosis, and this was reduced to 24% by LPA (Fig. 1B). These differences were statistically significant. Consistent with the survival promoting activity, LPA prevented Et-induced caspase 3-like activation in BJAB cells as detected by cleavage of the fluorescently labeled peptide in a caspase assay, as described under “Experimental Procedures” (Fig. 1C). Treatment of BJAB cells with 3.0 μm Et induced a 3-fold increase in caspase activity that was reduced to background by treatment with 1.0 μm LPA. To determine the amount of LPA required to protect B-cell lines from apoptosis, BJAB cells were treated with various concentrations (100 nm to 10 μm) of three forms of LPA (18:1, 18:0, and 16:0) in the presence or absence of 1.0 μm Et. The results indicate that as little as 100 nm LPA could protect BJAB cells from Et-induced apoptosis (Fig. 1D). LPA Protects Primary CLL Cells from Spontaneous and Fluinduced Apoptosis—Because LPA protects a CLL-like cell line (I-83) from apoptosis, we determined whether leukemic cells from CLL patients could also be protected from apoptosis by LPA. Primary CLL cells were treated with a range of LPA concentrations (0.1 μm to 10 μm), and the amount of spontaneous apoptosis was determined after 96 h. LPA protected CLL cells against spontaneous apoptosis at a concentration of 0.5 μm but failed to provide a protective effect at 0.1 μm (Fig. 2A). The protection at 0.5 μm was similar to the protective effect of 30% plasma isolated from CLL patients (Fig. 2A). This LPA concentration is similar to the concentration of LPA found normally in the plasma (0.4–0.6 μm) (3Mills G.B. Moolenaar W.H. Nat. Rev. Cancer. 2003; 3: 582-591Crossref PubMed Scopus (949) Google Scholar). LPA protection was also evident over a 96-h time course where at each time point LPA-treated cells showed reduced spontaneous apoptosis compared with cells grown in serum-free medium (Fig. 2B). In addition, primary CLL cells were incubated for 72 h in the absence or presence of LPA added once (1× LPA), added twice separated by 24 h (2× LPA), or added three times at 24-h intervals (3× LPA), and the amount of spontaneous apoptosis was determined. This revealed that the percentage of surviving cells increased from 10 to 24% upon further additions of LPA over the 72-h time course compared with untreated cells (Fig. 2C). In addition to spontaneous apoptosis, LPA provides protection against Flu-induced apoptosis in primary CLL cells. Primary CLL cells were treated with 10 μm Flu alone or in combination with 5.0 μm LPA. After 24 h, the level of apoptosis was determined as described under “Experimental Procedures.” In cells treated with Flu alone, ∼50% of the cells underwent apoptosis. In the presence of LPA, the percentage of apoptosis was decreased to ∼30% with the level of apoptosis in untreated cells being 20% (Fig. 3A). This represents a 50% reduction in the amount of Flu-induced apoptosis. Annexin V staining of primary CLL cells also confirmed these results, where LPA decreased Flu-induced apoptosis from 9.7 to 1.5% (Fig. 3B). In 26 patients studied, we found that LPA protected primary CLL cells against Flu-induced apoptosis in 12 cases (40%). In contrast, LPA did not protect normal B-cells against Flu-induced apoptosis (Fig. 3C). Plasma containing LPA from both normal volunteers and CLL patients showed protection against spontaneous induced apoptosis (data not presented). This suggests that the LPA protection of CLL cells is primarily due to altered responsiveness of CLL cells to LPA.Fig. 3LPA protects primary CLL cells against Flu-induced apoptosis.A, primary CLL cells isolated from 10 patients were treated with 10 μm Flu in the presence or absence of 5 μm LPA for 24 h. The cells were also treated with LPA alone or untreated (control). The amount of apoptosis was determined by acridine orange staining. Each point represents the percentage of apoptotic cells for individual patients, and the bar represents the mean. B, primary CLL cells were also treated with LPA and Flu similar to A, but the amount of apoptosis was determined by annexin V staining using flow cytometry. 7-AAD-stained cells represents cells with the plasma membrane has become permeabilized to the DNA binding dye. Annexin V was visualized by fluorescein isothiocyanate staining. The cells that were 7-AAD-negative and annexin V-positive were undergoing apoptosis. The percentage of cells in each quadrant was indicated within the quadrant. C, normal B-cells were isolated from two volunteers and treated with Flu and LPA similar to A. The amount of apoptosis was determined by acridine orange staining.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Primary CLL Cells Express Higher Levels of LPA1 Receptor Compared with Normal B-cells—LPA binds to four receptors, LPA1–4. LPA1 is the most widely expressed receptor and is expressed in B-cells (3Mills G.B. Moolenaar W.H. Nat. Rev. Cancer. 2003; 3: 582-591Crossref PubMed Scopus (949) Google Scholar, 17Anliker B. Chun J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 20555-20558Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar). By Western blotting, the level of LPA1 expression was found to be increased in primary CLL cells isolated from 12 patients when compared with normal B-cells isolated from four healthy individuals (Fig. 4A). To verify that the LPA1 antibodies are recognizing the receptor, primary CLL cells untransfected (lane 1), transfected with siRNA against LPA1 (lane 2), or transfected with scrambled siRNA (lane 3) were lysed and Western blotted for LPA1. Only cells treated with siRNA against LPA1 showed a reduction in the ∼50-kDa band corresponding with LPA1 molecular mass, whereas untransfected cells and cells transfected with scrambled siRNA failed to lower this band (Fig. 4B). Furthermore, nonspecific bands at higher molecular masses failed to change following siRNA against LPA1 transfection (data not shown). In addition, CLL cells that were protected from apoptosis by LPA showed higher expression for LPA1 compared with CLL cells that failed to respond to LPA and to normal B-cells (Fig. 4C). To confirm these differences in LPA1 expression, we performed RT-PCR to detect the mRNA for LPA1 in the CLL cells. In CLL cells that responded to LPA protection, the level of mRNA for LPA1 was higher than in CLL cells that failed to respond to LPA protection (Fig. 4D). LPA1 Mediates LPA-induced Cell Survival Responses—To determine the r

The death ligand, TRAIL (tumor necrosis factor-related apoptosis-inducing ligand), has shown great promise for inducing apoptosis selectively in tumors. Although many tumor cells are resistant to TRAIL-induced apoptosis alone, they can often be sensitized by co-treatment with DNA-damaging agents such as etoposide. However, the molecular mechanism underlying this therapeutically important synergy is unknown. We explored the mechanism mediating TRAIL-DNA damage apoptotic synergy in human mesothelioma cells, a tumor type particularly refractory to existing therapies. We show that Bid, a cytoplasmic Bcl-2 homology domain 3-containing protein activated by caspase 8 in response to TRAIL ligation, is essential for TRAIL-etoposide apo-ptotic synergy and, furthermore, that exposure to DNA damage primes cells to induction of apoptosis by otherwise sublethal levels of activated Bid. Finally, we show that the extensive caspase 8 cleavage seen during TRAIL-etoposide synergy is a consequence and not a cause of the apoptotic cascade activated downstream of Bid. These data indicate that TRAIL-etoposide apoptotic synergy arises because DNA damage increases the inherent sensitivity of cells to levels of TRAIL-activated Bid that would otherwise be insufficient for apoptosis. Such studies indicate how the adroit combination of differing proapoptotic and sublethal signals can provide an effective strategy for treating refractory tumors. These data indicate that TRAIL-etoposide apoptotic synergy arises because DNA damage increases the inherent sensitivity of cells to levels of TRAIL-activated Bid that would otherwise be insufficient for apoptosis. Such studies indicate how the adroit combination of differing proapoptotic and sublethal signals can provide an effective strategy for treating refractory tumors. Resistance to apoptosis is critical to tumor development and maintenance (1.Hanahan D. Weinberg R.A. Cell. 2000; 100: 57-70Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (21906) Google Scholar, 2.Johnstone R.W. Ruefli A.A. Lowe S.W. Cell. 2002; 108: 153-164Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1976) Google Scholar). In part, this is because activated oncogenes and deregulated proliferation are potent triggers of apoptosis that must be countermanded before tumors can arise (3.Evan G. Wyllie A.H. Gilbert C.S. Littlewood T.D. Land H. Brooks M. Waters C.M. Penn L.Z. Hancock D.C. Cell. 1992; 69: 119-128Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2764) Google Scholar). Moreover, because most cancer therapies act by inducing apoptosis in tumor cells, suppression of apoptosis is also likely a critical feature of chemo- and radioresistance (4.Schmitt C.A. Lowe S.W. J. Mol. Med. 2002; 80: 137-146Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). Restoring an effective capacity to execute apoptosis therefore represents an attractive general strategy for the selective therapeutic targeting of tumor cells.Relatively little is known concerning the mechanisms by which apoptosis is suppressed in cancers. However, because all tumor cells appear to retain the capacity to undergo apoptosis when subjected to sufficiently strong insults, apoptosis suppression in cancer cells in the main seems to involve dysfunctions in apoptotic and survival signaling pathways rather than lesions in the highly redundant basal apoptotic machinery itself (5.Green D.R. Evan G.I. Cancer Cell. 2002; 1: 19-30Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (898) Google Scholar). A frequent example of this is the mutational inactivation of the p53 pathway observed in most tumor cells. p53 is a transcription factor that integrates disparate stress and damage responses and couples them to the basal apoptotic machinery in great part through transcriptional modulation of effectors that impact on the mitochondrion (6.Fridman J.S. Lowe S.W. Oncogene. 2003; 22: 9030-9040Crossref PubMed Scopus (1122) Google Scholar). In previous work, we have shown that mesothelioma cells can be sensitized to TRAIL-induced apoptosis by various DNA-damaging signals (30.Liu W. Bodle E. Chen J.Y. Gao M. Rosen G.D. Broaddus V.C. Am. Thorac. Cardiovasc. Surg. 2001; 121: 61-67Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar), making the apoptotic synergy between TRAIL and DNA damage a valuable model for combinatorial therapeutics of particular relevance to the majority of solid tumors, which lack a functional p53 pathway. Synergy also appears to be selective for malignant mesothelioma cells; despite earlier experiments in which primary mesothelial cells had variable responses suggesting synergy (30.Liu W. Bodle E. Chen J.Y. Gao M. Rosen G.D. Broaddus V.C. Am. J. Respir. Cell Mol. Biol. 2001; 25: 111-118Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar); currently, with more careful harvesting and culturing, the primary cells consistently show a lack of synergy between TRAIL and DNA-damaging agents (see “Results”). We thus sought to understand the mechanism underlying this striking synergy between TRAIL and DNA-damaging agents in malignant mesothelioma cells.Using a combination of RNA interference and microinjection, we have perturbed the TRAIL pathway to dissect the molecular basis of the TRAIL-DNA damage synergy and show that it is mediated by the essential intermediary Bid, a BH3 protein that is a target for death receptor signaling pathways. We also show that TRAIL by itself causes low level cleavage of Bid that alone is insufficient to trigger apoptosis in mesothelioma cells. However, exposure of mesothelioma cells to sublethal DNA-damaging agents profoundly increases sensitivity to the pro-apoptotic effects of Bid. Hence, the combination of sublethal TRAIL and sublethal DNA damage efficiently triggers activation of the mitochondrial apoptotic program and death of mesothelioma cells.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESReagents—Human recombinant TRAIL (375-TL, histidine-tagged extracellular domain) was purchased from R&D Systems Inc. Renken C. Perkins G. Kluck R.M. Bossy-Wetzel E. Newmeyer D.D. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 150: 1027-1036Crossref PubMed Scopus (221) Google Scholar). Scavo L.M. Ernst J.D. Boylan A.M. J. Clin. Investig. 1996; 98: 2050-2059Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar). Yang L. Scavo L.M. Ernst J.D. Boylan A.M. J. Clin. Investig. 1996; 98: 2050-2059Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar).Microinjection and Fluorescence Time-lapse Microscopy—For microinjection, tBid was dissolved in phosphate-buffered saline together with dextran-conjugated Oregon Green (0.5% final concentration, Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR) as a co-injection marker. Cells were plated on sterile glass-bottomed coverslip dishes in a phenol red-free medium and, when adherent, exposed to either etoposide (10 μg/ml) or the Me2SO carrier (1:6000) for 15 h. Etoposide- or Me2SO-exposed cells were microinjected with either tBid (5 nm) or phosphate-buffered saline as described previously (35.Juin P. Hueber A.-O. Littlewood T. Evan G. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 1367-1381Crossref PubMed Scopus (302) Google Scholar). At least 100 cells in two discrete areas in each of two separate experiments were microinjected in each case. The estimated volume injected into each cell was 2–5 pl (36.Juin P. Hunt A. Littlewood T. Griffiths B. Swigart L.B. Korsmeyer S.J. Evan G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2002; 22: 6158-6169Crossref PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar), equivalent to ∼6,000–15,000 molecules of tBid. Prior to time-lapse analysis, all cells received fresh media containing propidium iodide (2 μg/ml).Microinjected cells were placed in a thermostatic chamber on an Axiovert S 100 TV microscope (Zeiss, Thornwood, NY). The chamber was maintained at 37 °C and continuously flushed with 7.5% CO2. Cells were imaged every 25 min with an Orca C4742–95 charged couple device camera (Hamamatsu Photonics, Hamamatsu City, Japan) at 8 bit using Openlab software (Improvision, Lexington, MA), which also controlled the XY-stage, shutters, and filter wheels. Phase contrast images were illuminated with a 100-watt halogen bulb while a mercury vapor lamp and automated excitation filter wheel were used to excite the fluorescent probes. Oregon Green was excited using a 480/25 bandpass filter, and propidium iodide was excited using a 525/40 bandpass filter. The emission from these two fluorophores were detected using a polychroic beamsplitter 86007bs (Spectra Services, Rochester, NY) followed by an automated emission filter wheel using 525/40 and 620/60 bandpass filters, respectively. Images for each time point were merged to generate a color time-lapse movie. Live microinjected cells remained green and adherent; dying cells rounded up, developed a red nucleus as they became permeable to propidium iodide, and lost their green color. Microinjected cells (green) were followed for their fate (survival or death), and survival was plotted versus time.RNA Interference—Bid suppression was accomplished using two rounds of transfection with a siRNA (antisense strand: UAU UCC GGA UGA UGU CUU CdTdT) (Xeragon, Inc., Huntsville, AL). An irrelevant RNAi (antisense strand: ACG UGA CAC GUU CGG AGA AdTdT) was used as a control (non-silencing). siRNA duplexes were transfected into target cells using Oligofectamine (Invitrogen) as described (37.Elbashir S.M. Harborth J. Lendeckel W. Yalcin A. Weber K. Tuschl T. Nature. 2001; 411: 494-498Crossref PubMed Scopus (8076) Google Scholar). Ther. 2001; 298: 865-872PubMed Google Scholar).RESULTSTo validate apoptotic cooperation between TRAIL and DNA damage, M28 and REN mesothelioma cells were exposed to various doses of TRAIL, etoposide, or γ irradiation, and apoptosis was determined 18 h later. At commonly used therapeutic doses (25 ng/ml TRAIL, 10 μg/ml etoposide, 12 gray of γ irradiation), each insult individually induced negligible apoptosis (Fig. 1, A–C), even when assayed as late as 72 h after the insult. Indeed, even at far higher doses (250 ng/ml TRAIL, 100 μg/ml etoposide, 50 gray of γ irradiation), each insult alone induced negligible apoptosis (data not shown). In contrast, exposure of mesothelioma cells to the combination of sublethal TRAIL (25 ng/ml) together with either sublethal etoposide (10 μg/ml) or γ irradiation (12 gray) induced substantial apoptosis (Fig. 1, a–c). No such enhancement of apoptosis was observed when the two genotoxic insults, etoposide and γ irradiation, were combined (data not shown). Moreover, the apoptotic synergy between TRAIL and DNA damage that we observed in M28 and REN mesothelioma tumor cells was absent in normal primary human mesothelial cells (Fig. 1d).It has been reported that DNA damage can sensitize cells to the effects of TRAIL through up-regulation of TRAIL receptor expression, specifically of DR5 (24.Wu G.S.
